entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP Field Service Management 2511
entry.content:
Welcome to SAP Field Service Management 2511 ‚Äì our final release in a year filled with exciting innovations for field service organizations. As always, we have summarized the key highlights and included demo videos for you to explore.

SAP Field Service Management 2511 continues our investment in AI-driven scheduling, mobile productivity, and streamlined workforce coordination. New capabilities in crew planning, the service map, the dispatching board, and the mobile app help organizations plan smarter, execute faster, and reduce administrative effort across the field service lifecycle.

For the complete list of all features in the 2511 release, click here.

Key Highlights in SAP Field Service Management 2511

  • Crew Management enhancements ‚Äì partial-day crew assignments and clearer visibility into where technicians are staffed throughout the day.
  • Service Map improvements ‚Äì lasso selection for geo-based bulk assignment and skills validation when scheduling directly from the map.
  • AI scheduling transparency and control ‚Äì exclude released activities during rearrange runs, use Best Matching Technician reports to understand ranking and technician selection, and leverage configurable service call summaries to quickly review all work performed.
  • AI-powered Smartform translation on mobile ‚Äì translate Smartforms into other languages in seconds while preserving structure, integrity, and context.
  • Faster mobile wrap-up with group checkout ‚Äì check out activities from multiple service calls in one step, with options for consolidated or separate reports.

AI-Driven Scheduling and Dispatching

Check out the highlights in the demo video below:


Exclude released activities during rearrange

Dispatchers must optimize routes and reduce travel time ‚Äì but once a job is released to a technician, it often should not be moved. In 2511, SAP Field Service Management introduces the ability to exclude released activities from schedule rearrange runs.

In practice, a dispatcher can select a technician‚Äôs schedule, run a rearrange based on the selected policy, and view proposed changes and sequences before applying them ‚Äì all while released jobs remain locked in place. This reduces the risk of disrupting work already communicated to the technician and provides a more controlled optimization experience, especially in high-volume operations. More info here. 

 

 

Service call summaries

From the service call, dispatchers and back-office staff can now execute an AI-generated service call summary to obtain an overview of all activities performed on a single service call. Furthermore, such summaries can easily be configured to represent only the most relevant information.

By consolidating key information into a single view, service call summaries reduce the time spent piecing together what happened on a job, and help dispatchers or back-office staff review, document, close, and move on to the next case more efficiently. More info here. 

 

Conditional color formatting in the activity list

To improve contextual awareness, dispatchers can now use conditional color formatting in the activity list. Instead of scanning long lists of jobs, planners can define simple conditions that change how activities appear.

For example, based on configuration, all jobs for a key customer such as Alpha Corporation might appear in blue, while IoT generated activities show in red. These visual cues help dispatchers quickly distinguish high-priority, automated, or specialized work without opening each activity. The result is faster triage, fewer misses, and a more intuitive way to work through large backlogs. More info here. 

 

Best Matching Technician scheduling reports

Best Matching Technician (BMT) helps dispatchers quickly identify the right resource based on skills, availability, and other criteria. With 2511, SAP Field Service Management adds scheduling reports for BMT to increase transparency into why certain technicians are selected ‚Äì and why others are excluded.

When running a BMT search, dispatchers can now see a report that explains the ranking of technicians, including which criteria contributed positively and where requirements were not met. Drilling into the report reveals the individual scoring per technician, making it easier to understand how the autoscheduler behaves in BMT scenarios. This added transparency builds trust in AI-assisted decisions and helps planners fine-tune their data and rules over time. More info here. 

 

Recurring reservations for planned time blocks

Managing training, safety sessions, or any other repeated commitments can become a manual burden when each time block must be created individually. In 2511, SAP Field Service Management introduces recurring reservations for person reservations.

Dispatchers can now define recurring patterns ‚Äì for example, schedule a technician for safety training over the next two weeks, every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 8:00 to 11:00. The recurring reservation can be managed as a series or on a single-day basis, with options to adjust dates, times, weekdays, and frequency. This simplifies repetitive reservation planning and makes calendars more accurate for both dispatchers and technicians. More info here. 

 

Mobile Field Service

Check out the highlights in the demo video below:


AI-powered Smartform translation

Smartforms are critical for capturing structured data in the field, but localizing them into multiple languages has traditionally required multiple manual steps. With 2511, SAP Field Service Management introduces AI-powered Smartform translation.

Using AI, customers can translate Smartforms into multiple languages in just a few steps. For example, an existing English Smartform can be translated into Spanish, resulting in a fully functional form for Spanish-speaking technicians. Translations preserve the form‚Äôs structure, integrity, and context, enabling field service organizations operating in multiple languages to deploy localized forms in seconds, rather than hours or days.

On mobile, technicians see the translated form in their native language, with all critical fields intact. This improves data quality, adoption, and user experience for global workforces. More info here. 

 

Group checkout across multiple service calls

Technicians frequently complete work for several service calls in a single route. Previously, group checkout reporting was limited to activities within one service call at a time. With 2511, SAP Field Service Management introduces group checkout across multiple service calls.

Technicians can now select activities from different service calls and perform a single checkout step, streamlining the wrap-up process at the end of a shift or route. They can choose whether to generate one consolidated report for all selected activities, or separate reports per service call.

This reduces administrative overhead, shortens the gap between execution and documentation, and helps ensure reporting remains compliant with internal and customer requirements. More info here. 

 

Service Map, Crews, and Crowd Service

Check out the highlights in the demo video below:


Lasso selection on the service map

The service map is central to location-aware dispatching. In 2511, SAP Field Service Management introduces lasso selection to help dispatchers assign groups of activities using geographic context.

On the map, dispatchers can draw a lasso around all jobs in a particular area, then drag the selected activities onto a technician‚Äôs schedule. The activities are automatically placed according to the organization‚Äôs predefined scheduling policy (for example, based on SLA). This approach combines visual, map-based planning with automated scheduling logic ‚Äì accelerating dispatcher workflows by reducing manual drag-and-drop, respecting geography, and assigning work in bulk. More info here. 

 

Skills validation when scheduling from the service map

Scheduling directly from the map becomes more intelligent with skills validation. When a dispatcher drags an activity from the service map onto a technician‚Äôs schedule, the system now checks for any skill conflicts.

If a technician lacks the required certification, skill, or qualification for the job, a notification appears, allowing the dispatcher to adjust the assignment before confirming. This ensures that requirements such as geography and skills are both considered in the scheduling process, helping organizations maintain safety and compliance while still working visually from the map. More info here.

 

Partial-day crew assignments

Crew Management in 2511 introduces support for partial-day crew assignments, enabling more precise allocation of technicians across multiple crews throughout the day.

Dispatchers can assign a technician to one crew in the morning and another crew in the afternoon. Time-specific assignments can be managed as a series or as individual days, with clear visibility into each technician‚Äôs crew allocation. For example, a technician may be staffed on Crew X from 8:00 to 12:00, then allocated to a Crew Y from 12:00 to 18:00.

These partial-day assignments give planners greater flexibility to maximize resource utilization for dynamic field service operations, while the dispatching board clearly reflects dynamic crew assignments throughout the day. More info here.

 

 

Crowd Service list view

For organizations working with external contractors, Crowd Service helps coordinate third-party resources. In 2511, a new list view provides a more efficient way to manage crowd assignments and activity distribution.

Dispatchers can review contractor jobs and take bulk action on groups of activities from a single list. This enhancement supports high-volume contractor operations where quick adjustments and bulk updates are essential. More info here.

 

Administration

Shell notifications with direct links

Shell notifications now support hyperlinks, making it easier to move from insight to action. For example, when a dispatcher is notified about events such as a closed activity, they can open the notification and jump directly to the relevant object with a single click.

This reduces navigation time, helps dispatchers stay focused in high-volume environments, and ensures that important events can be followed up on immediately, while linking to critical information. More info here. 

 

Enhanced admin control for client assignment

In 2511, admins can control which FSM clients each user may access ‚Äì for example iOS, Android, or shell only. At user level, you define the allowed platforms and block everything else, helping ensure technicians connect only from approved, managed devices and aligning FSM access with corporate mobility policies. More info here. 

 

Extensions

New commercial extension ‚ÄúSkill Manager‚Äù

A new third-party extension, Skill Manager from partner Elephantis, is now available in the SAP Field Service Management Extension Directory. Skill Manager helps field service teams manage technician skills in a grid-style view, with visual indicators for valid, expiring or expired skills, along with advanced filtering options. This makes it easier to keep certifications current and ensure the right technicians are assigned to the right work. More info here. 

 

Final Thoughts

SAP Field Service Management 2511 sharpens how planners, dispatchers, and technicians work together ‚Äì with clearer schedules, smarter maps, and faster mobile workflows.

Released-activity protection in rearrange simulations, BMT reports, recurring reservations, and service call summaries give dispatchers more control and transparency. Technicians benefit from AI-translated Smartforms, recurring reservations on mobile, and group checkout across service calls.

With lasso selection, skills validation on the map, and partial-day crew assignments, planners and dispatchers can align the right resources to the right work more efficiently ‚Äì whether they are internal teams or contractors.

We look forward to your feedback through Influence, the SAP Community, and upcoming webinars.

Check out other recent SAP Field Service Management releases:

  • SAP Field Service Management 2508
  • SAP Field Service Management 2505
  • SAP Field Service Management 2502
  • SAP Field Service Management 2411
  • SAP Field Service Management 2408
  • SAP Field Service Management 2405
  • SAP Field Service Management 2402

entry.title: Re: CDS VIEW About Credit Exposure
entry.content:
Dear @25103678,

In Public Cloud, there is no single released CDS view that reliably provides the full breakdown of totals across all credit exposure categories 100/200/300/400/500 in the same way the standard Fiori apps do.

What you observed with I_CreditExposureItem is expected by design:

  • I_CreditExposureItem reads credit exposure items from backend table UKM_ITEM
  • Category 200 (open A/R items) is not stored in UKM_ITEM, so the CDS view cannot return category 200 line items and therefore also doesn‚Äôt help for a full category breakdown

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003431583

What options are available:

1. If you need the correct total exposure, use the released CDS view I_CreditLimitUtilization. This is commonly used for total exposure / utilization scenarios. Be careful with its parameters, the FI-AR part can be excluded depending on how P_ReadLineItem is filled

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003517767

2. If you truly need a category-level breakdown (100/200/300/400/500)
There isn‚Äôt a released CDS that gives you that full breakdown out of the box. Practically you have these options:

  • Use I_CreditExposureItem for the categories it actually covers (typically SD/LE-related, like 100/400/500) and accept it‚Äôs not complete

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/93e5af96e585443b9481349e9fec8545.html

  • Raise an SAP request (influence / support) to release an API/CDS artifact that exposes the category totals in a stable way since I_CreditExposureItem is explicitly missing 200 by design

https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Flexible Pickup&Delivery Window Interpretation
entry.content:
Hi @GRABLERE 

we have the business requirement that the pickup and the delivery is on the same day. More specifically the pickup at the supplier is around 08:00 am till 10:00 am and the delivery at the destination location is around 13:00 pm till 15:00 pm the same day.

However, the Freight Unit is always calculating based on the time 00:00:00 am. This results in the problem, that the pickup date and time at the supplier is always 1 day earlier. For example it will be at 27.11.2025 on 23:10 pm after the deduction of the transport time. The shift calendar is also assigned to each location which matches the location opening hours from 08:00 am till 16:00 pm. This means the pickup at the supplier is always one business day earlier then the delivery at the destination location.

We are using SAP S/4 HANA TM Release 2022 and upgrade to Release 2023 in 1st Quarter 2026.

From SAP side, a modification in SAP TM - ideally in the Planning Profile or in the Freight Unit (SPRO) should be performed that during the transportation planning that the opening hours and closing hours should be included in the calculation. In addition, a selection should be possible that the freight transport will be executed on the same day.

I am looking forward to your comments - if this could be fixed through a SAP Note and also with a future SAP TM release.

Thanks.

entry.title: The Next Level of Global Payments: SAP Unlocks Enhanced Cross-Border Capabilities with TransferMate
entry.content:
In an increasingly interconnected global economy, businesses need payment solutions that are fast, transparent, secure, and seamlessly integrated into their ERP systems. That‚Äôs why the newly announced partnership between SAP and TransferMate represents a major step forward for finance and treasury teams.

Through this partnership, TransferMate‚Äôs cross-border payment service is now integrated directly into SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity as a non-bank payments provider bringing powerful and innovative global payment capabilities straight into SAP ERP solutions, including SAP Cloud ERP.

For organizations operating across multiple currencies and jurisdictions, this integration has the potential to significantly simplify international financial operations.

Traditionally, making international payments required organizations to juggle multiple banking partners, external platforms, or third-party portals. This fragmented processes introduced friction, increased operational risk, and added unnecessary costs that this partnership can solve

What You Can Expect from TransferMate‚Äôs integration into SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity

- Fast, transparent and efficient international payments without leaving your ERP

  • No additional portals or manual steps; enjoy seamless straight-through processing.
  • Automated flows from SAP ERP directly to TransferMate payment infrastructure reducing errors, manual intervention, and operational risk.

- Reduced complexity and improved scalability

  • SAP users can send and receive funds globally through a the unified and standardized payment infrastructure from TransferMate.
  • A scalable payment solution that grows with organizations expanding their international footprint.

- Greater transparency and control

  • End-to-end visibility from cross border payment initiation to settlement
  • Enhanced liquidity management with better payment tracking and more payment options.

- Strengthened compliance and security

  • TransferMate operates a fully regulated global payments network, ensuring adherence to local and international financial regulations.

Who Can Benefit?

Any organization using SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity‚Äîregardless of whether they are running SAP ERP, SAP S/4HANA, or SAP Cloud ERP‚Äîcan take advantage of this integration.

As companies continue to expand globally, the demand for frictionless, embedded financial tools will only grow. The integration of TransferMate into SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity marks a major step toward making global payments as simple, secure, and seamless as domestic transactions‚Äîdirectly from your SAP environment.

Want to Know More?

SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity

  • https://www.sap.com/germany/products/financial-management/multi-bank-connectivity.html
  • https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_MULTI_BANK_CONNECTIVITY

TransferMate

  • https://www.transfermate.com/
  • TransferMate Press Release

entry.title: Re: SAP ETD Alert push to MS Sentinel - OAuth2 configuration
entry.content: To give you a short answer, OAuth2 client_credentials is not supported in SAP HANA XS Classic. This is a design limitation of XSC as I know, which is why no Azure/Entra xsoauthclientflavor exists. A direct OAuth2-based ETD integration from XSC to Microsoft Sentinel is therefore not possible.

entry.title: Understanding Regex in JavaScript - A Beginner-Friendly Guide
entry.content:
Quick Introduction:

When working with JavaScript, we will often find ourselves needing to search, validate or modify text. That‚Äôs where Regex comes in.

In this blog, we will break down what regex is, why it‚Äôs useful, and how to start using it with simple examples.

 

What is Regex?

Regex is a powerful & smart search tool that lets you find patterns in text almost like giving your code a mini detective to look for clues inside a string.

Regex (short for Regular Expression) is a special pattern used to search, match and replace text.

In other words, regex is a pattern-matching language used in many programming languages, including JavaScript to:

  • Search for text
  • Match specific patterns
  • Replace parts of a string

For example, we might need to check if a sentence contains a word, extract all numbers from a paragraph or validate an email address. Regex makes these tasks fast, efficient and reliable.

 

Why do use Regex in JavaScript?

Because normal search is limited. With regex, we can do so much. Regex lets you write dynamic, flexible patterns to handle more advanced text operations. Here‚Äôs what you can do with it:

  1. Validate patterns

    Modify text based on matching patterns.
    Example: Remove extra spaces or replace characters.

  2. Extraction Text

    Check if a string follows a specific format.
    Example: Is this a valid email address?

  3. Replace text

    Pull out numbers, words or custom text patterns.
    Example: Find all digits in a message.

 

Simple and Practical Examples

Let‚Äôs look at how we can use regex in JavaScript with just a few lines of code.

  • Check if a word exists
const sText = "I love JavaScript";

const bResult = /JavaScript/.test(text);

console.log(bResult); // true
  • Find all numbers in a string
const sText = "My score is 95 out of 100.";

const sNumbers = sText.match(/\d+/g);

console.log(sNumbers); // ["95", "100"]
  • Replace spaces with dashes
const sResult = "hello world js".replace(/\s/g, "-");

console.log(sResult); // "hello-world-js"

 

How regex patterns are structured & how it works

Regex patterns in JavaScript are written between forward slashes:

/pattern/

Here are some common symbols:

Symbol

Meaning

\d

digit (0‚Äì9)

\s

whitespace (space, tab, etc.)

\w

word character (letters, numbers, _)

+

one or more

*

zero or more

Based on our requirement, we can combine these symbols to create almost any pattern we need.

In simple words, Regex is a smart text-searching tool in JavaScript. It helps us work with text faster, cleaner, and more efficiently, especially when dealing with patterns. Whether you're searching, matching or validating text, regex makes the process powerful, flexible and easy.

Thank you for taking the time to read this blog! I hope this helps you. If you found this helpful, please feel free to share your thoughts, feedback or questions in the comments. Let's keep learning and growing together!

Stay tuned for more Git-related commands in future blogs. Happy coding!

Dear experts, I‚Äôm new to blogging, please feel free to correct me if any information is inaccurate.

entry.title: Intercompany Cost allocation reconciliation ‚Äì Review Booklet
entry.content:
Area of Application - Intercompany Billing for Cross-Company Cost Accounting Postings (4AN)

Managing intercompany cost allocations during period-end closing can be complex and time-consuming. The new SAP Fiori app Intercompany Cost Allocation Reconciliation ‚Äì Review Booklet addresses these challenges by providing transparency across the entire document flow, from Management Accounting postings to intercompany billing and financial postings. It helps to ensure completeness and audit readiness.

Why This Matters

Cross-company cost accounting documents often originate from processes such as:

  • Time Recording for EPPM
  • Direct Activity Allocations
  • Service Confirmations
  • Concur Travel & Expense

These postings typically exclude tax and may not comply with global transfer pricing regulations. Legal invoices that include tax are required for compliance. SAP‚Äôs Resource-Related Intercompany Billing (RRICB) functionality (scope item 4AN - Intercompany Billing for Cross-Company Cost Accounting Postings) enables creation of intercompany invoices for these Management Accounting postings. Invoice creation is followed by the transfer to General Ledger (and Accounts Receivable), then the automatic mirroring of Accounts Payable documents in the receiving company. For additional details, please refer to the blog by @stefan_walz on Intercompany Cost Allocations in S/4HANA Cloud.

However, ensuring completeness by identifying services and expenses that are relevant for intercompany billing and are already billed, partially billed, or not yet billed, and then providing audit-relevant transparency during closing has been a critical challenge - until now.

Introducing the Intercompany Cost Allocation Reconciliation ‚Äì Review Booklet

This review booklet delivers:

  • End-to-end document flow reporting on intercompany cost allocations
    Trace postings from Management Accounting (CO) to Billing Documents and Accounts Receivable and Accounts Payable entries.
  • Status visibility
    Identify services and expenses that are billed, partially billed, or unbilled.
  • Audit-ready transparency
    Simplify reconciliation and reduce manual effort.

Scope

The review booklet covers intercompany transactions relevant for intercompany billing, including:

  • Timesheet postings (including contingent workers) and cancellations
  • Activity allocations (including margin postings) and cancellations
  • Reassigning/reposting costs and revenues (only cost reposting is considered for intercompany billing)
  • Settlement postings
  • Concur T&E
  • Universal Allocations and cancellations
  • Service Order Confirmations and cancellations

For the most current overview, see Intercompany Postings.

Out of scope:
Transactions posted via other processes (such as Advanced Intercompany Sales, General Journal Entries).

Prerequisites

The review booklet is delivered via feature toggle and is not automatically available in your system. To use it:

  • Activate scope item 4AN ‚Äì Intercompany Billing for Cross-Company Cost Accounting Postings.
  • Configure New Resource Related Intercompany Billing. For details, see
    Generate Intercompany Billing Request (New Solution).
  • Activate feature Intercompany Cost Allocation Reconciliation (CO_ICO_DOCFLOW) in the configuration activity Activate Features.

How to Use the App

The app is available in the Cost Accountant ‚Äì Overhead business role.
Steps:

Open the Intercompany Cost Allocation Reconciliation ‚Äì Review Booklet app.


Enter mandatory filters: Sender and Receiver Company Codes, Fiscal Year (CO), and Posting Period (CO).

Click Go to view documents that are classified as Billed or Unbilled.

The report uses clear labeling to identify information. Labels include the:

  • (CO) suffix for Management Accounting postings
  • (FI) suffix for General Ledger postings
  • Sender prefix for the invoice issuing/supplying company code
  • Receiver prefix for the invoice receiving/ordering company code

Constraints

The app is under active development. It was first delivered with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and is enhanced with 2602. We welcome and appreciate all feedback. Note there are currently some constraints in using the app:

  • Data will not display for the Receiver Journal Entry (FI) dimension unless you activate the feature Payables Posting for Classic Intercompany Invoice via bgPF (S4HC_SDBIL_ICO_IDOC_REMOVAL) in the Activate Features configuration activity. 
  • If you activate the use of general journal entries in the configuration step Activate Usage of General Journal Entries (107009) for New Resource Related Intercompany Billing, those records are not included in the document flows.
  • You must activate the new intercompany billing solution by performing the configuration for New Resource Related Intercompany Billing. 
  • Intercompany billing completed with the old solution appears as not billed in the document flow. Re-billed transactions using the new solution will display correctly.

Next Steps

Activate the feature, explore the app, and experience streamlined intercompany cost allocation reconciliation. Share your feedback to help shape future improvements.

entry.title: Re: Can you link/join a MATDOC record to the correspondin...
entry.content: In standard SAP S/4HANA, there is no guaranteed 1:1 technical link between MATDOC and an IDoc record. MATDOC stores the posted material document, while IDocs are only one of several possible posting sources. Depending on the business process, references may exist indirectly (e.g. document numbers or application logs), but a reliable join between MATDOC and IDoc is not provided as SAP standard.

entry.title: Re: Public Cloud - Debit/Credit Shift Between FSV Nodes -...
entry.content:
Good day @william_p 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Universal Journal Entry, Debit/Credit Shift Between FSV Nodes, Defining the Debit/Credit Shift

The Debit/Credit Shift between FSV Nodes is only for reporting-time presentation rule, which is used only during financial statement rendering. The status is not stored in ACDOCA, it is also not exposed through any CDS view or API and it also does not provide any flag that indicates whether an account was posted as an asset or liability after shift. That means you cannot retrieve the shift configuration in the FSV using a program.

You can access data like G/L account classification such as Asset, Liability, Equity, Expense through CDS views like I_GLAccountInChartOfAccounts. You can then join this with journal entries through A_JournalEntryItemAPI01 or I_JournalEntryItem. However, the shifted representation used in FSV cannot be extracted.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Can not restore SAP HANA 1.0 SP12 COMPLETE_DATA_BACKU...
entry.content:
This behavior is expected. A COMPLETE_DATA_BACKUP from SAP HANA 1.0 is system-specific and cannot be restored to another server unless the target system matches the original system ID, topology, and configuration. A fast ‚Äúsuccessful‚Äù recovery that does not actually restore data typically indicates this mismatch.

For cross-system restores, SAP supports restoring full data backups (without system context) or performing a proper system copy following the SAP HANA system copy guide.

Please refer to the SAP HANA Administration Guide for supported recovery scenarios.

SAP HANA ‚Äì Copying a Database Using Backup and Recovery: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HANA_PLATFORM/6b94445c94ae495c83a19646e7c3fd56/ea70213a0e114ec29724e4a10b6bb176.html

SAP HANA ‚Äì Backup and Recovery (Overview): https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/saphana/3361895687.html

entry.title: Re: Separate invoice for specific item

In SAP Sales and Distribution, items can be invoiced separately by using standard billing split criteria such as billing relevance, item category, billing block, or custom split logic. Whether this can be achieved without custom development depends on the specific business scenario and system setup.

entry.title: Re: Workflow BAM approval error FCLM_BAM_MAINT 094
entry.content: hi, we had same error message and tried to fix with SWIA, even SWWL etc. nothing worked for us, but colleague  found a report FCLM_BAM_CLEARDIRTYREQ and the corrupt fiori work items were gone

entry.title: Re: Extended RAM not showing in HANA database
entry.content: This is expected behavior. In SAP HANA, newly added physical RAM is not picked up automatically. The memory visible in HANA Studio is controlled by the system‚Äôs memory allocation at startup. A restart of the SAP HANA system is required so HANA can detect and use the additional RAM. The global_allocation_limit = 0 setting means ‚Äúautomatic,‚Äù but it still applies only after restart.

entry.title: Re: SAP Community Stammtisch Berlin ‚Äì Christmas Edition
entry.content: Thank you for linking the original. I thought it would be embedded as a thumbnail and open on a click, but it just got scaled down.

entry.title: Re: Creating multiple material master records with MM17
entry.content: No, MM17 in SAP standard is not intended to create new material master records. The Import Data from File option in MM17 supports mass changes of existing materials only, which is why no ‚ÄúData Records to be Created‚Äù option is offered. For creating multiple new materials, SAP standard approaches are transactions like MM01 with batch input, LSMW, or other data migration tools, depending on release.

entry.title: Re: Technique to import and activate calculation views
entry.content: The calculation views can be imported and activated only via supported content mechanisms, not via plain SQL. The standard approaches are using HDI containers / deployment (HANA Cloud) or delivery units / repository-based tools (on-premise). Programmatic activation via SQL or a public ‚ÄúHANA API‚Äù is not supported as I know. Automation is typically done through HDI build/deploy pipelines, transport mechanisms, or SAP-supported lifecycle tools, depending on platform and version.

entry.title: Re: MDG v8 HANA 2.0 SPS07
entry.content: Upgrading the SAP HANA database from one SPS to another (e.g. SPS05 ‚Üí SPS07) does not require changes on the MDG or ERP application side, as long as the target SPS is released and compatible with your ERP 6.0 / MDG 8.0 stack.

entry.title: Re: How to Preview data of SAP HANA View as other user ?
entry.content: It is not supported to preview data as another user unless you log on with that user. HANA SQL and data preview always run with the effective session user.

entry.title: A Hands-On Tutorial for Clean Core RAP Development
entry.content:
Introduction

In this workshop, we will build a simple Item business object using the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP) on an SAP BTP trial system.

RAP is SAP‚Äôs strategic programming model for developing cloud-ready, Fiori-enabled business applications in ABAP. It provides a clean, end-to-end programming model where you can define business objects, behaviors, services, and UI-ready projections in a structured way.

In this blog, we will:

  • Create a database table for items.

  • Define CDS root and projection views.

  • Implement behavior definitions with CRUD, and enhance it with actions, validations and determinations.

  • Create a virtual element.

  • Expose the business object as an OData service.

  • Preview it in Fiori.

By the end, you will understand how RAP objects are structured, connected, and how Clean Core principles are applied in a real example.

Why RAP?

  • Cloud-ready: SAP‚Äôs standard for S/4HANA cloud extensions and custom apps.

  • Clean Core compliant: No modifications to standard objects; all extensibility is via APIs.

  • End-to-end model: Business logic, UI, draft handling, and authorizations all in one place.

  • Consistency: Automatic CRUD, locking, and draft handling.

  • Fiori-ready: Generates OData services consumable by Fiori Elements.

  • Productivity: Faster development than classical ABAP or BOPF.

Environment Setup

For this demo, we use ABAP Development Tools (ADT) in Eclipse connected to an ABAP on Cloud project on an SAP BTP trial system. This setup gives us access to all RAP development tools and lets us preview Fiori apps directly from Eclipse.

If you‚Äôre setting this up for the first time, SAP provides a step-by-step tutorial to install Eclipse IDE, add the ABAP Development Tools (ADT) plugin and connect to your SAP system. Download the Eclipse IDE and add the ABAP Development Tools (ADT) Plugin | SAP Tutorials 

Useful ADT Shortcuts

Here are some useful ADT keyboard shortcuts for the ABAP development in Eclipse.

Info: You can display the full list of available shortcuts in the Show Key Assit in ADT by pressing Ctrl+Shift+L.

 

Part 1: Simple BO

Step 1: Create a Package

Before creating RAP objects, we need a package to organize them. Packages are like folders in Eclipse‚Äîthey help manage all the development objects together.

1. In Eclipse, right-click your ABAP on Cloud project ‚Üí New ‚Üí ABAP Package.

2. Enter package details

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Why this matters:

  • All RAP objects (tables, CDS views, behavior definitions, service definitions) should be in the same package.

  • It ensures clean core compliance, meaning your custom objects don‚Äôt modify standard SAP objects directly.

 

Step 2: Create Database Table

The database table is the foundation of your RAP business object. For this example, we‚Äôll create a table called ZITEM02 for our Item BO. 

1. Right-click your package ‚Üí New ‚Üí Other Repository Object ‚Üí search for "Database Table".

2. Add the fields and mark item_id as the primary key.

@EndUserText.label : 'Item Table'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table zitem_02 {

  key client            : abap.clnt not null;
  key item_id           : sysuuid_x16 not null;
  name                  : abap.char(50) not null;
  description           : abap.char(100);
  price                 : abap.dec(10,2);
  status_code           : abap.char(5) not null;
  local_created_by      : abp_creation_user;
  local_created_at      : abp_creation_tstmpl;
  local_last_changed_by : abp_locinst_lastchange_user;
  local_last_changed_at : abp_locinst_lastchange_tstmpl;
  last_changed_at       : abp_lastchange_tstmpl;

}

3. Activate the table.

The table ZITEM_02 serves as the persistent layer for your RAP business object. All data is stored here. 

 

Administrative Fields:

local_created_by/ local_created_at ‚Üí track who created the record and when.

local_last_changed_by / local_last_changed_at ‚Üí track local changes before activation (important for draft-enabled objects).

last_changed_at ‚Üí tracks the last committed change; used as the ETag for locking and consistency.

Why Admin Fields Matter:

RAP automatically uses them for draft management, locking, and optimistic concurrency control. Even if your app is simple, including them makes your BO ready for enhancements such as validations, actions, and side effects.

 

Step 3: Create CDS 

1. Root View 

The root view sits on top of the database table and defines the entity structure for your business object. It is the source for the behavior definition.

1. Right-click the database table ‚Üí New Data Definition 

2. Select the Root View Entity template.

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Root View Entity for Item'
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
define root view entity ZR_ITEM_02
  as select from zitem_02
{
  key item_id               as ItemId,
      name                  as Name,
      description           as Description,
      price                 as Price,
      status_code           as StatusCode,

      local_created_by      as LocalCreatedBy,
      local_created_at      as LocalCreatedAt,
      local_last_changed_by as LocalLastChangedBy,
      local_last_changed_at as LocalLastChangedAt,
      last_changed_at       as LastChangedAt
}

Table = raw persistence.

Root view = business-level representation, enriched with semantics, annotations, and ready for behavior logic.

The root view defines the primary key item_id to match the table.

2. Projection View

The projection view is built on top of the root view and serves as the entry point for service exposure. Here, we select which fields are exposed in the transactional OData service. We can also include UI annotations to guide Fiori Elements in rendering the app automatically.

1. Right-click the Root View CDS ‚Üí New Data Definition 

2. Select the Projection View template. 

The root view contains the core business data and logic, while the projection only exposes what the frontend needs. This way, we don‚Äôt modify or clutter the core data model with UI-specific details, keeping the core stable and extensible.

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Projection View for Item'
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
define root view entity ZC_ITEM_02
  provider contract transactional_query
  as projection on ZR_ITEM_02
{
  key ItemId,
      Name,
      Description,
      Price,
      StatusCode
}

For today, I‚Äôll keep the UI annotations minimal here and show how to add them cleanly in a metadata extension later, which keeps our projection view tidy and focused on data exposure.

 

Step 4: Create Behavior Definition

The behavior definition specifies how this entity behaves at runtime: which operations are allowed, It maps fields from the root view to the database table, and how draft actions are handled.

1. Right-click the Root View CDS ‚Üí New Behavior Definition

Since the purpose of this first example is to display the list report, we only need to map fields from the root view to the database table. 

managed implementation in class zbp_r_item_02 unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for ZR_ITEM_02 alias Item
persistent table zitem_02
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
etag master LastChangedAt
{
  create ( authorization : global );
  update;
  delete;
  field ( readonly, numbering : managed ) ItemId;

  mapping for zitem_02
    {
      ItemId      = item_id;
      Name        = name;
      Description = description;
      Price       = price;
      StatusCode  = status_code;
      LastChangedAt = last_changed_at;
      LocalCreatedAt = local_created_at;
      LocalCreatedBy = local_created_by;
      LocalLastChangedAt = local_last_changed_at;
      LocalLastChangedBy = local_last_changed_by;
    }
}

 

  • readonly ‚Üí The field cannot be changed by the user. RAP ensures it is protected in the frontend and backend.

  • numbering : managed ‚Üí RAP automatically generates unique values for this field when a new entity is created. You don‚Äôt need to write your own logic for primary keys like UUIDs or sequences.

     

The behavior projection allows us to expose only a subset of behavior from the main entity for a specific service. This is useful if we want different services to expose different parts of the behavior without modifying the core behavior definition.

projection;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for ZC_ITEM_02 alias Item
{
  use create;
  use update;
  use delete;
}

 

Step 5: Create Service Definition

The service definition declares which projection views are exposed as OData services. Here, we expose our projection view, making our User BO available for Fiori or API consumption. Service definitions are protocol-agnostic and can later be consumed via different bindings.

@EndUserText.label: 'Service Definition for Item'
define service ZSD_ITEM {
  expose ZC_ITEM_02 as Item;
}

 

Step 6: Create Service Binding

Right-click the Service Definition ‚Üí New Service Binding

Finally, the service binding connects the service definition to a specific protocol, such as OData V2 or V4. After activation, Publish the service and it can be accessed directly from Fiori elements or any OData client.

 

At this stage, our Business Object is not draft-enabled and does not support create/update/delete yet.
This means the Fiori Elements application shows a read-only list report, and because the table is empty, the preview will be blank.

This step is intentional ‚Äî it confirms that:

  • the CDS views are correct

  • the projection is exposed

  • the service binding is active

  • the app renders successfully with no errors

Even with no data, seeing the list report appear is an important milestone. In the next sections, we will add draft support and enable full CRUD operations.

 

Part 2: Enabling Draft, CRUD Operations, and Transactional Behavior in the RAP Business Object

In Part 1 of this series, we created the foundation of our RAP application:

  • A clean core‚Äìcompliant database table

  • The CDS root view entity

  • The projection view

  • A minimal behavior definition

  • A service binding that exposes our object to Fiori

At that stage, the generated application was intentionally read-only, serving as a good starting point to verify that the service and CDS structure work correctly.

Now, in Part 2, we take the next major step: turning our read-only object into a full transactional Business Object using the managed RAP BO approach. This includes:

  • Activating Create, Update, and Delete support

  • Enabling Draft handling for safe data entry

  • Allowing the Fiori Elements app to automatically render UI flows such as Edit, Save, Delete, and Discard Draft

  • Preparing the BO for further business logic enhancements (which we will add in Part 3)

Why We Enable Draft in RAP?

Draft is one of the key features of Fiori Elements applications.

Before enabling it, it‚Äôs important to explain why draft is needed.

Users expect modern UI behavior

In modern SAP Fiori apps, users do not commit their changes immediately. Instead:

  • They can start editing an object.

  • Leave the page.

  • Navigate back later.

  • Recover their unsaved changes.

This improves the UX significantly and eliminates accidental data loss.

Draft prevents incomplete database commits

Draft ensures that:

  • Partial or inconsistent data is never saved.

  • Users can enter complex data in multiple steps.

  • Locks on active instances are minimized.

This is especially important in enterprise systems with many concurrent users.

RAP provides draft automatically

Thanks to RAP‚Äôs managed BO runtime, draft functionality requires no custom code ‚Äî only a few declarations in the behavior definition.

 

Step 1: Updating the Behavior Definition of the Root Entity

1. Add with draft;

2. Add draft table zitem_02_d;

This associates the BO with a draft table.

If the draft table does not exist yet, ADT will offer to create it automatically.

3. Click on "Quick assist" ( CTRL + 1 )

 

@EndUserText.label : 'Draft table for entity ZR_ITEM_02'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #EXTENSIBLE_ANY
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table zitem_02_d {

  key mandt          : mandt not null;
  key itemid         : sysuuid_x16 not null;
  name               : abap.char(50);
  description        : abap.char(100);
  price              : abap.dec(10,2);
  statuscode         : abap.char(5);
  localcreatedby     : abp_creation_user;
  localcreatedat     : abp_creation_tstmpl;
  locallastchangedby : abp_locinst_lastchange_user;
  locallastchangedat : abp_locinst_lastchange_tstmpl;
  lastchangedat      : abp_lastchange_tstmpl;
  "%admin"           : include sych_bdl_draft_admin_inc;

}

Draft tables contain:

  • Table fields

  • Administrator fields

  • Temporary user changes

This table supports parallel editing and safe drafts.

4. Additional Draft Actions and What They Do

In RAP, the draft handling pattern can be extended beyond the basic actions .
For more advanced scenarios ‚Äî especially when working with optimized draft flows, background checks, or multi-step editing ‚Äî we can include the following actions:

  draft action Activate optimized;
  draft action Edit;
  draft action Discard;
  draft action Resume;
  draft determine action Prepare { }

Beyond the basic Edit / Activate / Discard pattern, RAP provides additional draft actions to improve performance and user experience.

  • Resume ‚Äì restores an existing draft so users can continue where they left off.

  • Prepare ‚Äì pre-fills data before the user sees the draft instance.

These actions require no manual coding unless you want to enhance them, and together they deliver a modern, safe, Fiori-compliant editing workflow.

5. Add total etag LastChangedAt;

This ETag is used by RAP to guarantee concurrency and data consistency.
It prevents situations where one user accidentally overwrites changes made by another user.
It is also required for draft handling and for the Fiori Elements UI, which relies on this timestamp to detect outdated edits.
RAP automatically manages this field, updating it whenever the record is changed.

6. Update the Behavior Projection

The projection behavior definition exposes the business behavior to the Fiori UI and the OData service. Even if the root BO supports create, update, delete, and draft actions, they must be explicitly enabled in the behavior projection. Without this step, Fiori Elements will not show the Create/Edit/Delete or draft buttons. The projection layer ensures clean core separation by keeping internal logic in the root BO while exposing only the required operations to the UI.

projection;
strict ( 2 );
use draft;

define behavior for ZC_ITEM_02 alias Item
{
  use create;
  use update;
  use delete;

  use action Activate;
  use action Edit;
  use action Discard;
  use action Resume;
  use action Prepare;
}

7. Create Behavior Implementation Class 

Eclipse generates a global ABAP class with the naming convention. 

 

Understanding What ‚ÄúManaged Implementation‚Äù Means

Standard CRUD is generated automatically

You do not need to write: create/ update/ delete logic, draft save/ load logic, locking logic, ETag management

RAP provides all of this out of the box.

The class is only for custom behavior

This is where we will later implement validations (check input before save), determinations (auto-fill fields), actions (mark item as completed), unmanaged logic, feature control, authorization checks, if needed.

But for Part 2 (Draft + CRUD), the class stays empty.

8. Creating the Metadata Extension (UI Annotations)

After creating the projection view and exposing the BO behavior, we need to define how this data should be displayed in Fiori Elements apps.

This is where metadata extensions come into play. They allow you to add UI annotations without touching the core CDS view, keeping your implementation clean and following Clean Core principles.

Right-click on the Consumption View ‚Üí New ‚Üí Metadata Extension

@Metadata.layer: #CORE
annotate entity ZC_ITEM_02 with
{
  @UI.facet: [
         {
             purpose: #STANDARD,
             type: #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE,
             label: 'Items',
             position: 10
         } ]
  ItemId;
  @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 10, label: 'Name' }]
  @UI.identification: [{ position: 10, label: 'Name' }]
  Name;
  @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 20, label: 'Description' }]
  @UI.identification: [{ position: 20, label: 'Description' }]
  Description;
  @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 30, label: 'Price' }]
  @UI.identification: [{ position: 30, label: 'Price' }]
  Price;
  @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 40, label: 'Status Code' }]
  @UI.identification: [{ position: 40, label: 'Status Code' }]
  StatusCode;

}

The metadata extension defines how the Item BO is displayed in Fiori Elements. Using annotations like @ui.lineItem and @ui.Identification, we specify which fields appear in the list report and object header. The @ui.facet groups the fields into a standard identification card. Placing these annotations in a metadata extension layer ensures Clean Core compliance, separating UI concerns from business logic, while enabling a ready-to-use Fiori preview.

After adding draft-enabled behavior and the metadata extension, let‚Äôs see the results in the Fiori preview:

Create Button appears automatically at the top of the list report and clicking it opens a draft object, ready for entry.

Delete Button appears at the top of the list report.

List Report displays all annotated fields without manually selecting columns, shows all items.

Object Page: clicking a list entry opens the object page.

Edit Button is visible on the object page, clicking it opens the draft for editing, supporting safe modifications before activation.

This confirms that draft-enabled RAP objects, combined with metadata annotations, automatically generate a full-featured Fiori UI: list report, object page, and CRUD actions‚Äîall without writing UI code manually.

 

Part 3: Enhancing the Item BO with Actions, Determinations, Validations, and Virtual Elements

to be continued

entry.title: Annual Leave termination balance based on anniversary date
entry.content:
Hi Team,

The clarified Termination Rule for Annual Leave is as follows:

  • Annual leave entitlement depends on the employee‚Äôs employment anniversary date.

  • Before the anniversary date ‚Üí previous year‚Äôs entitlement applies.

  • After the anniversary date ‚Üí new year‚Äôs entitlement applies.

  • If termination occurs before the 15th, that month is not counted for accrual.

  • If termination occurs on/after the 15th, that month is included in the accrual.

Example Outcomes

  1. Termination: 14-Mar-2025 ‚Üí 2 days

  2. Termination: 14-Mar-2026 ‚Üí 2 days (anniversary not reached)

  3. Termination: 16-Mar-2026 ‚Üí 3 days (month included)

  4. Termination: 4-Nov-2027 ‚Üí 12 days (mixed entitlement by year)

  5. Termination: 18-Nov-2027 ‚Üí 13 days (additional month counted)

Please review and confirm if this logic can be configured in the system, or let me know if you would like to discuss it over a call.

entry.title: How can we Implement Augmented Reality (AR) in SAP MDK?
entry.content:
Hello experts,

I'm building an iOS application using SAP MDK. My requirement is to integrate the AR (Augmented Reality) functionality within SAP MDK. Use case would be an AR assist for a technician from remote expert.

I tried adding an Add-on Feature of Augmented Reality in the SAP Mobile Services Cockpit.
Following these links: Configuring Augmented Reality | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: Understanding the Purpose of the Predecessor ProjectField in SAP Ariba
entry.content:
In SAP Ariba, the Predecessor Project field is designed to help users create logical, traceable, and organized relationships between projects. Although users often assume the predecessor feature is intended for copying data, its primary purpose is to build project relationships that support reporting, visibility, and structured project hierarchies.

This article explains what the Predecessor Project field is used for, how it differs from the Copy from Project capability, and why predecessor projects remain selectable even after they are completed or approved.

What Is the Purpose of the Predecessor Project Field?

The Predecessor Project field serves two main purposes:

  1. Establishing a Link Between Related Projects

Selecting a predecessor project allows you to link the current project to an existing one.

  • This relationship does not require copying values from the predecessor.
  • If the sole intention is to copy data, users should instead use the Copy from Project option.
  • The predecessor linkage provides context, relationships, and traceability between projects.

2.   Supporting Hierarchical Reporting (Subprojects)

When you assign a predecessor project, the system can treat the current project as a follow-on or subproject in reporting views.

  • This helps teams and organizations visualize chains of related initiatives.
  • It ensures reporting structures reflect how projects truly relate to one another.

Predecessor Project vs. Copy from Project

Although both functions may prepopulate fields, they serve different purposes.

Predecessor Project

  • Selecting a predecessor from the dropdown menu creates a follow-on relationship.
  • Fields that exist in both the predecessor and the current project may be pre-populated.
  • The main goal is linking projects, not cloning them.
  • The predecessor project retains its identity and lifecycle.

Copy from Project

  • Creates a copy of an existing project.
  • The copied project retains most of the original project‚Äôs attributes.
  • You cannot select a new template or project type when copying.
    • The new project inherits the project type and uses the latest published version of the template originally used.
  • This option is intended for reusing structure and content‚Äînot linking projects.

Why Is a Predecessor Project Still Available After Completion or Approval?

A predecessor project remains selectable even after it is completed, approved, or closed, because its function is not tied to its status. The predecessor mechanism exists to maintain continuity and logical connections across related initiatives, regardless of where each project is in its lifecycle.

The purpose of a predecessor is not to transfer or copy data‚Äîit is to maintain a conceptual and reporting link.

Example Scenario: ABC Corporate Electronics Procurement

Consider the following use case:

  • ABC  manager creates a parent RFI project to collect information from suppliers.
  • Once the RFI is completed, each team member creates their own individual sourcing or contracting project to procure electronic devices based on their personal needs.
  • Even though the original RFI project is already completed, it remains available as a predecessor.
  • Each team member sets the RFI project as their predecessor, creating a clear traceable line between the parent project and all the follow-on projects.

This ensures:

  • All child projects remain connected to the original sourcing initiative.
  • Reporting and audits reflect a complete project hierarchy.
  • Stakeholders can easily understand the sequence and relationship between efforts.

How Field Copying Behaviors Are Controlled in SAP Ariba (Advanced Field Configuration)

Whether fields are copied, synced, or inherited across projects (including predecessor and copied projects) depends on Advanced Field Configuration settings. These settings determine when and how field values flow between parent, predecessor, or copied projects.

Below are the key configuration options:

  • Sync in copied project on create:
    • This option copies fields when using the Copy from Contract field on create or Actions > Copy Project.
  • Sync in follow-on project on create:
    • This option copies fields when using the Actions > Follow-on Project or by selecting a Predecessor Project.
  • Sync in subagreement on create:
    • This option copies fields when using the Parent Agreement field on create or Actions > Sub Agreement.
  • Sync in subproject on create:
    • This option copies fields when using the Actions > Create Subproject (from the Documents tab).
  • Sync in subproject on change:
    • Makes the field in a subproject be auto pulled from its parent project whenever the field is updated in the parent project, including when the subproject is created.
  1. These options are not available for all fields and must be configured by an SAP resource.
  2. Present under Advanced tab of Field Configuration for specific fields.

 

Summary

Feature

Predecessor Project

Copy from Project

Purpose

Link projects logically

Reuse content by creating a copy

Effect

Creates follow-on relationship; may prefill shared fields

Creates a new project based on another

Template control

Uses template of the current project

Inherits template of the original project

Best used for

Reporting structure, traceability, subproject relationships

Cloning project design, structure, and content

SAP Ariba Sourcing SAP Ariba Contracts #Predecessor Project

entry.title: Transitioning from EBICS 2.5 to EBICS BTF 3.0 in SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity
entry.content:
Transitioning from EBICS 2.5 to EBICS BTF 3.0 in SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity (S/4HANA Private Cloud)

The jump from EBICS 2.5 to EBICS 3.0 is more than a version number change, it‚Äôs a rethink of how corporate payments are described, routed and accepted by banks. If your landscape includes SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity for S/4HANA Private Cloud, the move to EBICS 3.0 and the new Business Transaction Format (BTF) model deserves careful planning. Here‚Äôs a clear and practical guide that explains what‚Äôs changing, which SPRO settings to check, what might cause issues, and how to manage the migration safely.

EBICS version timeline

 

Why EBICS 3.0 matters

EBICS 3.0 introduces the Business Transaction Format concept, replacing the old EBICS order type approach. That change brings two big wins:

  • Standardization across countries (for example, it adds support for countries that older EBICS versions didn‚Äôt cover).
  • More flexible, future-proof transaction processing banks get clearer, structured transaction metadata (BTFs), which reduces ambiguity and improves processing.

But with those benefits come configuration changes and some technical bumps you‚Äôll want to avoid.

Quick comparison: EBICS 2.5 vs EBICS 3.0

EBICS 2.5

  • Uses order types as subcategories of message types.
  • Historically German-centric in practice.
  • Requires ERP source systems to determine and set order types for bank acceptance.

EBICS 3.0

  • Replaces order types with BTFs (Business Transaction Formats).
  • Designed for multi-country standardization.
  • More flexible parameter handling and importantly maintains reasonable backward compatibility, but only if you configure it right.

The BTF concept and what to watch out for

BTFs are the new atomic building blocks that banks use to interpret and accept your payments. That means:

  • BTFs must be defined in the MBC connector and correctly determined at payment creation time.
  • If BTF parameters are missing or wrong, banks will often reject the message.
  • Mapping from your legacy order types to BTFs is not always 1:1; expect to revisit business rules and routing logic.

Common implementation challenges

Technical

  • BTF parameters not populated: especially when payments originate from Advanced Payment Management. Outbound messages may lack required BTF header data unless parameter mappings are corrected.
  • Order type mapping conflicts: leftover rules for EBICS 2.5 order types (e.g., in ‚ÄúMaintain EBICS Order Type Determination‚Äù) can create conflicts or simply become irrelevant.
  • Authentication changes: some EBICS 3.0 scenarios require tweaks to user authentication flows (VEU-process adjustments, two-user approvals).

Operational

  • Temporary payment disruptions: misconfigured BTFs mean rejected payments until fixes are applied.
  • Bank coordination: banks must confirm the exact BTF parameter set they expect, and you‚Äôll want scheduled windows for joint testing.

A practical migration approach

Stage 1: Assessment & planning

  • Inventory existing EBICS 2.5 order type configs and all active EBICS connections.
  • Map payment workflows that rely on order-type logic.
  • Contact banks: confirm EBICS 3.0 support, collect bank-specific BTF specs, and book testing windows.

Stage 2: System configuration (SPRO)

BTF Type Definition
Multi-Bank Connectivity Connector ‚Üí Outbound Processing ‚Üí EBICS BTF ‚Üí Maintain EBICS BTF Types

  • Create BTF types with clear names and descriptions that match bank specs.

BTF Determination Rules
Multi-Bank Connectivity Connector ‚Üí EBICS BTF ‚Üí Maintain EBICS BTF Type Determination Rules

  • Configure rules so payment media are assigned the right BTF automatically.
  • Use wildcard handling where sensible (Company Code, House Bank ID, Account ID, Payment Method). Note: some fields should not be wildcards because their values can be meaningful.

Parameter Assignment

  • Map BTF parameters to message headers so outbound EBICS messages carry what the bank expects. Validate against the bank‚Äôs specification.

When you maintain the BTF settings in the adapter, they are passed along as extended headers in the MBC messages. The EBICS adapter can then be set up to read and use the values from these extended headers:

BTF Parameter Name

BTF Parameter Description

Mandatory

ADMIN_ORDER_TYPE

Administrative Order Type

x

SERVICE_NAME

Service Name

x

MSG_NAME

Message Name

x

MSG_NAME_VARIANT

Message Name: variant

 

MSG_NAME_VERSION

Message Name: version

 

MSG_NAME_FORMAT

Message Name: format

 

SERVICE_OPTION

Service Option

 

SCOPE

Scope

 

CONTAINER_TYPE

Container Type

 

SIGNATURE_FLAG

Signature Flag

 

Stage 3: Testing & validation

  • Set up a test tenant in MBC and connect with banks‚Äô test endpoints.
  • Run end-to-end payment scenarios: confirm BTF parameters show up correctly and banks accept or provide actionable rejections.
  • Iterate until the errors are resolved and acceptance is consistent.

Stage 4: Production migration

  • Roll out EBICS 3.0 to a small set of banking connections first and monitor closely.
  • Keep EBICS 2.5 connections active while you validate each bank migration.
  • Once stable, decommission obsolete order type logic and fully switch to BTFs.

What becomes obsolete and what stays

Phase out

  • The old Order Type Determination configurations used in EBICS 2.5.
  • German-only EBICS customizations that are no longer required.
  • Legacy parameter mappings tied to order types.

Keep / rework

  • Core MBC connector items: message number ranges, SSF application parameters, Secure Store & Forward profiles, inbound processing steps.
  • Advanced routing and sender/receiver mappings (they remain relevant, though may need minor tweaks).

SPRO: exact activities you‚Äôll use

New EBICS 3.0 activities

  1. Maintain EBICS BTF Types: define BTFs.
  2. Maintain EBICS BTF Type Determination Rules: auto-assign BTFs during payment creation.
  3. Approval User Determination: map ERP approvers to EBICS users for runtime approvals.
  4. EBICS User Mapping: a direct mapping of approval users to EBICS users.
  5. Static EBICS Users: optional, if you don‚Äôt use dynamic determination.

Obsoleted activity

  • Maintain EBICS Order Type Determination (the legacy order type activity) this is replaced by BTF determination rules.

User approvals, a few key points

  • At runtime, the system matches ERP users to EBICS users based on your mapping logic so approvals presented to the bank carry the expected EBICS user identity.
  • Ensure your Approval User Determination and EBICS User Mapping are tested together with BTF assignments, mismatches here cause approvals to fail or be rejected by the bank.
  • If BTF parameters are missing, user mapping won‚Äôt save the payment, populate BTF headers correctly first, then confirm user mapping.

Monitoring and operations

After go-live, improve monitoring to catch BTF-related issues quickly:

  • Use the Manage Bank Messages Fiori app for transaction tracking.
  • Rely on the Connector Monitor for processing details and root-cause analysis.
  • Implement better error handling and retries specifically targeting BTF parameter failures (these are the most common cause of bank rejections during the switch).

Final thoughts

Moving to EBICS 3.0 and BTFs is a strategic, long-term win: multi-country standardization, clearer transaction semantics and better compatibility with modern banking expectations. But the migration is not ‚Äúflip a switch.‚Äù It affects configuration, determination logic, user approval mapping and your relationship with banks.

Take the migration in phases, coordinate closely with banking partners, and make testing your worst-case scenario before you touch production. Done right, the effort pays off with fewer ambiguities, cleaner message headers, and a future-ready payments architecture.

entry.title: Re: SAP ERP ECC Warranty Inheritence in Functional Locati...
entry.content:
I couldn‚Äôt find a solution for the inheritance problem. I have now written an ABAP report that inherits the warranty start and end dates from the superior functional location to all subordinate locations and writes them into the BGMKOBJ table. I‚Äôm making the code available to all tormented PM administrators. Live long and prosper!

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report Y_PM_TP_INHERIT_WARRANTY
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& vererbt Garantie Beginn und Ende des √ºbergeordneten Technischen Pl.
*& an alle untergeordneten Pl√§tze und schreibt in die Tabelle BGMKOBJ.
*&
*&
*& Author     : Student, Christian
*& date       : 28.11.2025
*& kind of p. : Report    (x)     Batch-Input ( )      Include   ( )
*&              Sonstiges/others  ( )                  Modulpool   ( )
*&
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* √Ñnderungshistorie                                                    *
* Datum      Benutzer:                  Grund                          *
* ---------- ----------------- --------------------------------------- *
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
REPORT y_pm_tp_inherit_warranty.

PARAMETERS: p_tplnr TYPE iflot-tplnr OBLIGATORY,
            p_test  AS CHECKBOX DEFAULT abap_true.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_child,
         tplnr TYPE iflot-tplnr,
         objnr TYPE iflot-objnr,
       END OF ty_child.

DATA: lv_objnr_parent      TYPE iflot-objnr,
      lt_child             TYPE TABLE OF ty_child,
      lv_pattern           TYPE string,
      lv_status            TYPE string,
      wa_bgmkobj_parent    TYPE bgmkobj,
      wa_bgmkobj_child     TYPE bgmkobj.

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Autorit√§tspr√ºfung (nur Hinweis)
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
AUTHORITY-CHECK OBJECT 'I_FL' ID 'TPLNR' FIELD p_tplnr ID 'ACTVT' FIELD '02'.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
  WRITE: / 'Hinweis: Autorit√§tspr√ºfung fehlgeschlagen. Bitte Berechtigungen pr√ºfen.'.
ENDIF.

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* 1. √úbergeordneten Platz lesen
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
SELECT SINGLE objnr
  FROM iflot
  INTO @LV_objnr_parent
  WHERE tplnr = @p_tplnr.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
  MESSAGE '√úbergeordneter technischer Platz nicht gefunden' TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* 2. Gew√§hrleistungsdaten f√ºr √ºbergeordneten Platz lesen
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
SELECT SINGLE *
  FROM bgmkobj
  INTO CORRESPONDING FIELDS OF @wa_bgmkobj_parent
  WHERE j_objnr = @LV_objnr_parent.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
  MESSAGE 'Keine Gew√§hrleistungsdaten f√ºr √ºbergeordneten Platz gefunden' TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* 3. Untergeordnete Pl√§tze lesen
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
lv_pattern = p_tplnr && '%'.

SELECT tplnr, objnr
  FROM iflot
  INTO TABLE @LT_child
  WHERE tplnr LIKE @LV_pattern
    AND tplnr <> @p_tplnr.

IF lt_child IS INITIAL.
  MESSAGE 'Keine untergeordneten technischen Pl√§tze gefunden' TYPE 'I'.
ENDIF.

WRITE: / '√úbergeordneter Platz:', p_tplnr,
       / 'Testlauf:', p_test.

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* 4. Verarbeitung der untergeordneten Pl√§tze (vereinfacht mit MODIFY)
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
LOOP AT lt_child ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<child>).
  IF p_test = abap_true.
    lv_status = |SIMULATION: Platz { <child>-tplnr } w√ºrde aktualisiert oder neu angelegt werden.|.
  ELSE.
    CLEAR wa_bgmkobj_child.
    wa_bgmkobj_child = wa_bgmkobj_parent.
    wa_bgmkobj_child-j_objnr = <child>-objnr.
    wa_bgmkobj_child-erdat   = sy-datum.
    wa_bgmkobj_child-erzei   = sy-uzeit.
    wa_bgmkobj_child-gaerb   = 'X'.

    " MODIFY entscheidet automatisch ob INSERT oder UPDATE
    MODIFY bgmkobj FROM @wa_bgmkobj_child.

    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      lv_status = |Platz { <child>-tplnr } erfolgreich verarbeitet.|.
    ELSE.
      lv_status = |Fehler bei Platz { <child>-tplnr }.|.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.

  WRITE: / lv_status.
ENDLOOP.

IF p_test = abap_false.
  COMMIT WORK.
  WRITE: / '√Ñnderungen wurden gespeichert.'.
ELSE.
  WRITE: / 'Testlauf abgeschlossen. Keine √Ñnderungen gespeichert.'.
ENDIF.

entry.title: Re: the billing date in 5D2 scope item
entry.content:
Good day @omega-ou 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at this good comprehensive Blog on: Advanced Intercompany Sales & Stock Transfer in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

What you experienced is not per say, a fault in the system design, rather intended to ensure compliance.

In summary, the control dates do not determine the billing date for IV2 and F2 in public cloud, even in 5D2. It always defaults to the Good Issue Date of the outbound delivery. Which means the transfer of Control Actual Dates whether internal or external are only used for revenue and COGS recognition but not for billing date determination.

Due to the clean-core principle that guides the public cloud, the billing logic is protected. The system, for that reason does not allow you to override the billing date either through system configuration, SSCUI or the use of BAdI. Hence why you are only allowed to adjust them manually.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Advanced Intercompany Stock Transfer, Transfer of Control of Goods, Billing Due List, Process Billing Due List, Intercompany Billing

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Configuring Employer Compliance Task for WTPA Forms
entry.content:
Hi @SunithaR,

I found where the problem was. There was a step missing in the configuration. It seems to be necessary, at least for scenarios where the assignment is needed for corporate representatives.

After creating the rules using the scenarios "Assign Corporate Representative User ID for Employer Compliance Task and Signatory in Country Compliance Form" and "Select Employer Compliance Task and Signature for Country Compliance Configuration", they showed as assigned (the green check in the left side of the business rule name) but they were not assigned, actually.

To solve it, I went to "Manage Data" -> "ComplianceConfiguration" -> and searched for the compliance forms US_WTPA. In there, I assigned the business rules I created (maybe this is the step missing for you @Akanksha).

After that, this was the process I observed:

1 - Onboardee completed all compliance forms (except I-9). Instead of generating the signature step for the onboardee right away, there was an additional step assigned to the corporate representative (no notifications were sent here - not sure if there is a standard template for that).

2 - When proxying to Corporate Representative, no home page tiles were created for this task. I needed to access the task via "To-Do Panel" -> "Complete Compliance Tasks".

3 - After submitting it with the corporate representative, the signature step was created for the onboardee.

4 - After signing the compliance forms with onboardee, a signature task was generated for the corporate representative (home page tile) - @SunithaR I noticed a problem in this home page tile. It was generated with the name "Complete Form I-9 Signature" but when I open it, it refers to the WTPA form.

5 - After signing the form with the corporate representative, the compliance forms got completed.

I hope it helps whoever sees this message.

Regards,

Lucas

entry.content:
Dear @JastinC1,

In Public Cloud you generally can‚Äôt put the system behind your own VPN the way you would with an IaaS/private landscape. SAP manages the environment and network edge, so you don‚Äôt get a customer-controlled network firewall/VPN termination in front of the tenant

More details from SAP Community:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/how-to-setup-vpn-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition/qaq-p/12767497

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/configure-conditional-authentication-for-application

IP-based restriction directly in SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) using Risk-Based / Conditional Authentication. IAS supports policies that can use IP ranges as conditions for allow/deny or step-up

SAP community guidance for Public Cloud calls out using IP-range risk-based authentication for this kind of restriction

More details below:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/ip-listing-restriction-in-sap-s-4-hana-public-cloud-edition/qaq-p/12744765

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/what-is-identity-authentication

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/how-to-define-risk-based-authentication-rules-with-sap-hana-cloud-platform/ba-p/13179186

Important practical information:

  • You must use the public IP address seen on the internet (corporate NAT/VPN egress), not internal RFC1918 ranges like 10.x.x.x.
  • If you have proxies make sure you allowlist the actual egress IPs users will appear from

More details below:

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/risk-based-authentication-in-sap-cis/qaq-p/13700362

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003469077

Summary:

If the requirement is users must be on company network implement:

  • Corporate IdP Conditional Access (preferred, centralized) or
  • IAS Risk-Based/Conditional Authentication with IP allowlist + default denny and require VPN for offsite users so their egress IP matches the allowed range

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: What is the (end user) APO AlertMonitor equilivant in IBP ?
entry.content:
Hello experts,

we are underway to start with IBP after using APO for more than 15 years now. We got the first custom alert definitions created including a subscription and alerts creation works etc. But what is the (closed) equivalent of the APO AlertMonitor (/SAPAPO/AMON1, see attached picture) so that enduser can check their alerts in a "1stop-shopping-approach" ? 

We have 2 places in IBP as far as we understand it correctly:

  • APP - "Monitor Custom Alerts" - it seems to have limited info on the start screen and does not directly allow a "profile" usage, an alert counter is missing (how many alerts do I have for Alert XYZ etc.) and its not grouping the alerts by subscription into single line type of overview -  is this more for Admins or what is the purpose?
  • APP - "PlannerWorkspace" (with the tab "Alerts") - this looks a little bit closer - but once you open a subscription you don't have a view like in APO to navigate to another block of alerts (you have to go back etc.) and the workbook component (dataview) on the right side remains always open although you have not yet selected a concrete alert.

It looks to use the PWS with the tab "Alert" is probaly the place being close to the AlertMonitor in APO - or would you recommend to use the Monitor Custom Alerts for Endusers ?

Regards

Thomas
