entry.title: Re: Backgrround job for automatic creation PGI
entry.content: Automated Order to Invoice  We automated the outbound logistics process so that once the sales order is created, the system automatically generates delivery, performs picking, posts goods issue, and creates the invoice using scheduled background jobs in SM36‚Äîresulting in real-time processing and operational efficiency. So we can take one scenario is like in cash sales process, Where customer will take the goods from the factory outlet.  We create a SO and Delivery, Picking, Packing, PGI and Invoice will happen automatically. First, I create an order with system Set Up 1. Immediate delivery as X in SO Document type Control 2. Create item category with VOV7 by copy TAN 3. Create Delivery type with OVLK by copy LF (Need to Maintain in sales document type)  4. Create Billing type with VOFA by copy F2 (Need to maintain in sales document type)  5. Maintain item category determination  Or by EDI we can create the Sales Order Now we need to set up for Picking 1. we need to go T-code V/38,  Need to check which is our Output type for picking (Std.= EK00) 2. Go to VP01SHP, Click on Shipping V4 3. Go to Picking List and Here we need to assign the output device with shipping type and check the immediate check box 4. Now we need to go OVLT and assign the output type and set time as a Immediately + Save Now hope our Picking will update and System will do the Picking Now we need to set up for PGI 1. For this we need to do Background Job for the t code VL60G with your shipping point and Create a Variant 2. Create a background job by SM36 with Programme WS_MONITOR_OUTB_DEL_GDSI and Created Variant Now hope System will do the PGI. Now we need to set up for Invoice 1. For this we need to do Background Job for the t code VF04 or VF06 with your shipping point and Create a Variant 2. Create a background job by SM36 with Programmed SDBILLDL or RV60SBAT and Created Variant. Now hope System will do the Invoice.

entry.title: Re: Backgrround job for automatic creation PGI
entry.content:
This is my question only.

Automated Order to Invoice

We automated the outbound logistics process so that once the sales order is created, the system automatically generates delivery, performs picking, posts goods issue, and creates the invoice using scheduled background jobs in SM36‚Äîresulting in real-time processing and operational efficiency.

So we can take one scenario is like in cash sales process, Where customer will take the goods from the factory outlet and that time only they take the goods.

We create a SO and Delivery, Picking, Packing, PGI and Invoice will happen automatically.

First, I create an order with system Set Up
1. Immediate delivery as X in SO Document type Control
2. Create item category with VOV7 by copy TAN
3. Create Delivery type with OVLK by copy LF (Need to Maintain in sales document type) 
4. Create Billing type with VOFA by copy F2 (Need to maintain in sales document type) 
5. Maintain item category determination

Now we need to set up for Picking
1. we need to go T-code V/38,  Need to check which is our Output type for picking (Std.= EK00)
2. Go to VP01SHP, Click on Shipping V4
3. Go to Picking List and Here we need to assign the output device with shipping type and check the immediate check box
4. Now we need to go OVLT and assign the output type and set time as a Immediately + Save

Now hope our Picking will update and System will do the Picking

Now we need to set up for PGI
1. For this we need to do Background Job for the t code VL60G with your shipping point and Create a Variant
2. Create a background job by SM36 with Programe WS_MONITOR_OUTB_DEL_GDSI and Created Variant

Now hope System will do the PGI.

Now we need to set up for Invoice
1. For this we need to do Background Job for the t code VF04 or VF06 with your shipping point and Create a Variant
2. Create a background job by SM36 with Programme SDBILLDL or RV60SBAT and Created Variant.
Now hope System will do the Invoice.

entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì In-depth analysis of SAP Fiori content changes during system upgrade
entry.content:
TL;DR SAP Fiori content can change during upgrades. Not only the app lifecycle influences the app availability and usage, attributes of SAP Fiori apps (e.g. tile title, application resource, ‚Ä¶) can change as well and this will have an impact on your end users UX, if you don‚Äôt pay attention and address it via change procedures.

If you upgrade your SAP S/4HANA system version, there will be changes in the availability of SAP Fiori apps. Some will be deprecated, available with successor, obsolete/unavailable, or are not affected by any change. This will be highlighted by the SAP Fiori Upgrade Impact Analysis.   

The necessary prerequisites related to the SAP Fiori Upgrade Impact Analysis can be found either in the SAP Blog SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Upgrade Impact Analysis or on the SAP Help page SAP Fiori Upgrade Impact Analysis.
Additionally, the following SAP Blog offers you insights in the app lifecycle of SAP Fiori apps: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Upgrade Faster ‚Äì Managing app lifecycle impacts on users.

After reading through these documentations, you should be aware of the SAP Fiori upgrade process and what the app lifecycle statuses (deprecated, obsolete, available with successor, ‚Ä¶) are referring to.

Let‚Äôs get into the details of what changes can occur in SAP Fiori content during a system upgrade.

Type of changes to SAP Fiori content

  1. Changes in the features/functionalities of SAP Fiori apps
    Please check the What's New Viewer - ABAP Platform to get updates on the functional changes happening in the SAP Fiori apps.
  2. Changes to feature/functionalities in the SAP Fiori launchpad
    Please check the What's New Viewer - ABAP Platform to get updates on the new features delivered with each SAP Fiori FES version.
  3. Changes to SAP Fiori Launchpad App Descriptor Items (LADI)
    This is the focus topic of this SAP Blog, as it is scope of the ‚ÄúAdvanced Upgrade Impact Analysis‚Äù.

SAP Fiori App changes on LADI

There is a multitude of changes that can happen during an SAP Fiori Upgrade.

In this blog I decided to use an upgrade scenario from SAP S/4HANA 2022 FPS01 to SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02 as a case example. During my evaluation I used the SAP standard roles to illustrate the changes that can happen.
We are going to use four types of change priorities to describe the change impact of relevant LADI attributes that impacts end users.


To get a list of all LADI relevant attributes we are using the transaction /UI2/FLPCA for exporting‚Ä¶ With this export we are able to get a quick overview of the SAP Fiori content in customer or SAP standard roles.

In SAP S/4HANA 2023 the report has a total of 63 columns that can be exported.
Out of these 63 a total of 22 can contain end user relevant changes.
If you see that a column appears multiple times, that column can contain different type of issues.

For instance,  the column Title/Subtitle/Information can contain issues related to:

  • Change of information displayed on tile
    This is rated as Medium
  • {Reference Lost} or {Reference Lost to Backend Catalog}
    This is rated as High

Below, you see an overview of the different end user relevant columns prioritized by possible impact during system upgrade.

*rating of these attributes can vary based on your end users change resilience/innovation acceptance threshold

Now, let‚Äôs dive into some specific examples to make this topic more tangible.

One more comment before showing some examples‚Ä¶
These apps are chosen without any additional intention behind displaying them.
The examples are chosen at random

1. Title/Subtitle/Information changed

As an example, we are going to take the roles SAP_BR_CONTRACT_MANAGER_CCM and SAP_BR_CONTR_MGR_ROYALTIES.
The structure of this field is as follows: Tile Title ‚Äì Tile Subtitle / Tile Information

In the picture below you can see that we have a small change, information from the Tile Title has been written into the Tile Subtitle.

How is this change reflected in the SAP Fiori launchpad?

2. Application resource changed

The following example from role SAP_BR_BUDGET_RESPONSIBLE shows that in the business catalog SAP_PSM_BC_BDGTRESP_MD the application resource for the tile ‚ÄúDisplay Grant‚Äù changed.

As depicted in the screenshot below, taken from SE93, the programs behind these transactions are different. This can have a functional impact.
Your functional colleagues need to review, if the application is still suited to perform all the necessary process steps designated to that application.

3. Semantic Object and Action changed

The combination of semantic object and action is used for the intent-based navigation.

As this is relevant for the navigation network/flow of applications connected with each other, a potential change can have an impact on the process flow of end users working with these applications.

If such a change is detected, the applications in its process flow need to be verified again.

With these examples shown, I don‚Äôt want to discourage you in performing upgrades.
Rather I want to highlight the importance of proper testing during upgrades.
The SAP Fiori content can and will change during a system upgrade.
Preparing for this change via change management is crucial to ease your end users into the new SAP S/4HANA version.

Changes in Z-roles created with SAP standard content

You followed the SAP best-practices and copied the SAP standard business catalogs to your own Z-version of these content entities?
Independent of whether you are using SAP created business catalogs or business catalogs created by you, they are all referencing to the content from the technical catalogs.
If a LADI object changes in the original persistence (technical catalog), the LADI object will be changed in the reference (business catalog), as well.
Therefore, even if you use Z-catalogs and reference content from SAP technical catalogs, your content will be affected from the changes coming with the SAP Fiori upgrade as well.

This is a double-edged sword:

  1. You are getting changes from SAP standard content by referencing from SAP technical catalogs and therefore stay close to SAP Standard.
  2. Changes to content in SAP technical catalogs are reflected in your referenced content added to your business catalogs and hence will be in your system after the upgrade.

Since this is the best practice for multiple reasons, your content is going to change with an upgrade of the system version.

Now to the big question: can we support you in the process of SAP Fiori upgrade by highlighting these changes directly in your customer specific roles?

Advanced Upgrade Impact Analysis

The Advanced Upgrade Impact Analysis is a SAP delivered service providing you with the results via a service report to give you clarity on SAP Fiori changes during an upgrade.
We are combining the learnings from analysing the content in one source of truth and highlight the changes with recommendations fitting to each of these different changes.

What is required to perform the Advanced Upgrade Impact Analysis?

We need two different exports to perform the in-depth analysis.

  1. SAP Fiori content of customer source system, this is an export of all customer relevant role data before the upgrade.
  2. SAP Fiori content of customer target system, this is an export of all customer relevant role data after the upgrade.

 

It is recommended to export the role data from the development system before performing an upgrade to a higher SAP S/4HANA version.
Ideally, no further changes to the role content are taken after the export has been performed.

The analysis of the content changes is conducted on entry level.
An entry is equal to an application, in a role in a catalog.

E.g. ME23N is in business catalog Z_BC_MM_PUR_DIS assigned to role Z_BR_MM_PUR_DIS.
Each entry in your custom roles can be sorted into the following categories:

1. Unchanged

This means that all end user relevant attributes of the SAP Fiori content remain unchanged and the application lifecycle status is ‚Äúavailable‚Äù or ‚Äúunknown‚Äù.

2. Changed

This means that at least one end user relevant attribute of the SAP Fiori content changes and/or the application lifecycle status is ‚Äúobsolete‚Äù, ‚Äúdeprecated‚Äù, ‚Äúavailable with successor‚Äù.

Changes on LADI level are highlighted, e.g. change on Title/Subtitle/Information.

3. Added

This means that the entry is part of the SAP Fiori content after the upgrade, e.g. got added by your administrators before taking the export or can‚Äôt be matched correctly due to reference lost issues.

4. Removed

This means that the entry is part of the SAP Fiori content before the upgrade, but not after.
E.g. got deleted by your administrators before taking the export or can‚Äôt be matched correctly due to reference lost issues

 How can you order this service?

If you already are a Premium Engagement customer, contact your SAP Technical Quality Manager (TQM) to discuss how Premium Engagement Service can help you with a custom-tailored and efficient service portfolio to make your project a success!
With the Advanced Upgrade Impact Analysis, we are happy to support you with tailored insights and guidance for your system upgrade!
Discover further insights into SAP Premium Engagement and explore how an international team of specialists can assist you in maximizing the value of your SAP solutions.

entry.title: Re: Error message 5XU DRC Germany
entry.content: The error SOAP:1007 SRT: Unsupported xstream found ("HTTP Code 401: Unauthorized") in Scope Item 5XU (E‚ÄëInvoice Germany) means that the system cannot authenticate against the external e‚Äëinvoicing service. In Public Cloud, this typically happens because the communication arrangement is missing valid credentials or user assignment. You should not reset or bypass this ‚Äî instead, check the communication arrangement, the assigned communication user, and the AIF recipient mapping.

entry.title: Re: Public Cloud: converting material weight from kilogra...
entry.content:
What you can do is

  • Maintain sales unit of measure in the sales view of the material master (e.g. LB for US sales org).
  • Maintain purchase unit of measure in the purchasing view (e.g. LB for US vendor).
  • Maintain warehouse unit of measure in WM/EWM settings if needed.

These units are tied to the material master but can differ by application area (sales, purchasing, warehouse). You cannot have a different base unit of measure per plant or sales org ‚Äî that‚Äôs a global setting.

entry.title: Re: Mapping of Lump Sum Target
entry.content:
I'm a bit confused as to what you are trying to accomplish - if you want lump sum to calculate off a different value other than current salary then changing the "basedOn" makes sense.

If you are just trying to default a value in when worksheets are launched but still allowing managers to change the default value within guidelines, you should be using the standard guidelines to do this.

  • What is lump sum a % of? If it's a % of salary, changed the based on back to current salary. Sounds like something is incorrect with your target and it's actually 0 which is why your % is read-only as any % of 0 is going to be 0 so it won't let you enter anything. Would need screenshots to confirm you are populating the correct target - is your field reloadable? If not if you didn't relaunch worksheets that's likely why it's 0 on worksheets but visible in the UDF.
  • to default a value use the guidelines and the "default" column - set to a default amount or percentage depending which you want under "change rule settings". This is just an example I mocked up where everyone defaults to 100 but the guideline is wider for people with a higher PM rating.

  •

entry.title: Integration & Exception Monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM for SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model
entry.content:
Hi Everyone!

I want to give a heads-up that this SAP Community blogpost will be a long read, since we will walk through every step of Integration and Exception Monitoring in SAP PaPM Cloud (Standard Model) and some extra tips on the configuration. Stick with it, and you‚Äôll come away with a complete end-to-end understanding. üòä

This guide focuses on the SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model. Even in this model, you can already leverage Integration and Exception Monitoring capabilities provided by SAP Cloud ALM. These tools allow you to:

  • Track the health of your database connectivity and integration
  • Detect and analyze exceptions in real time.
  • Gain transparency into system behavior without disrupting business operations.

By combining SAP PaPM Cloud with SAP Cloud ALM‚Äôs monitoring framework, you can establish a proactive approach to identifying issues early and ensuring smooth data flows.  

Follow each step carefully and in sequence to ensure your monitoring setup works exactly as intended and gives you the confidence that your SAP PaPM Cloud environment is being tracked reliably.

Alright, let‚Äôs dive in!

Step 1: Subscribe to SAP Cloud ALM

This is the foundational step of the Integration & Exception Monitoring setup. Think of SAP Cloud ALM as your control tower for the monitoring service.

Follow below procedure to subscribe and have access to SAP Cloud ALM:

  1. Provision SAP Cloud ALM following the procedure in Requesting SAP Cloud ALM.
  2. Perform required configuration activities in Required Setup for SAP Cloud ALM.

After completing the activities, including assignment of the appropriate role, you‚Äôll have full access to the SAP Cloud ALM.

Step 2: Create Service in SAP Cloud ALM

In this step, you will now register your SAP PaPM Cloud in the Landscape Management of SAP Cloud ALM.

Prerequisite: Before proceeding with the next step, make sure you have the write access to the Landscape Management application of the SAP Cloud ALM. For the details on the roles and authorization, see Landscape Management | Roles and Authorization

Once the prerequisite is completed, you may now proceed with below procedure:

In your SAP Cloud ALM, go to the Operations tab > Management and Automation. Then, select Landscape Management

The Landscape Management application will open in a new screen. In the Landscape Management, select Services & Systems in the left-hand navigation. Then, select Add > New Service

The next step is to register your SAP PaPM Cloud application in SAP Cloud ALM by providing the information below. Once all information is provided, click the Save button.

FIELD

VALUE

Name

Enter the name for the new service

Description

Optional field

System Number

 Enter the system number that‚Äôs available in SAP for Me. It's a unique identifier or alias for the tenant and is based on the tenant name

Service Type

Important: Make sure to select SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud

Role

Select the Role of your SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud

Root URL

Enter the domain URL of your SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud

Logon URL

Enter the domain URL of your SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud

Deployment Model

SAP Public Cloud

After clicking Save, your newly registered SAP PaPM Cloud service will appear in the list, showing the status as New. Select the newly registered solution to check the Details and Supported Use Cases for your application.

On the next screen, you will see details of your newly registered service as well as supported use cases for your solution.

Additional Information:

  • Please take note of the Service ID. You will need this information in the next step when we create a destination to SAP Cloud ALM.
  • To set the service to Active status, you must enable and configure the use cases which we will cover in the next steps.

Step 3: Create Service Instance and Service Key for SAP Cloud ALM

In this step, you will need to set up a secure account (client ID) and password (Client Secret) so that other SAP applications like SAP PaPM Cloud can securely connect to the SAP Cloud ALM. You will need to perform this step in SAP Cloud ALM.

  1. Create an API service instance and service key for SAP Cloud ALM in the SAP BTP Cockpit as described in Retrieving Service Credentials.
  2. Add required authorization scopes as described in Managing Scopes.

Hint: Download and save the service key file. You‚Äôll need the details in Step 4 ‚Äì creation of Destination to SAP Cloud ALM

Step 4: Create Destination to SAP Cloud ALM

In this step, you will now connect SAP PaPM Cloud to the SAP Cloud ALM by creating a ‚ÄúDestination‚Äù. Follow the procedure below to complete this step:

Remember the Service Key you downloaded in Step 3? Take note of the details below as you will need them when setting up the Destination.

Login to your SAP PaPM Cloud subaccount and from the left-hand navigation, go to Connectivity and select Destination. Click Create to add a new Destination. In the pop-up window, choose From Scratch and then click Create.

In the Main Properties section, maintain the following parameters:

FIELD

VALUE

Name

Enter ‚ÄúPaPM_CloudALM‚Äù (default destination name) or assign a unique destination name.

Note: This will be used later in the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud Standard Model Setting (Step 6). If you choose a different name, other than PaPM_CloudALM, you need to check and ensure it is also configured in the Settings application., see Configure SAP Cloud ALM Destination in Settings.

Type

HTTP

Description

Optional ‚Äì enter any description for the destination

Proxy Type

Internet

URL

<CloudAlmServiceKey.endpoints.Api>

Authentication

OAuth2ClientCredentials

Client ID:

<CloudAlmServiceKey.uaa.clientid>

Use mTLS for token retrieval

Leave this unmarked

Client Secret

<CloudAlmServiceKey.uaa.clientsecret>

Token Service URL

<CloudAlmServiceKey.uaa.url>/oauth/token

Token Service URL Type

Dedicated

Use Basic credentials for token service

Leave this unmarked

Client Trust Store Configuration

Use default, keep this marked

In the Additional Properties section, click Add Property, then add the property below. Then, choose Create to save your changes.

FIELD

VALUE

papm-service-id

Enter the Service ID of the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud service in SAP Cloud ALM.

Note: Information in the papm-service-id must be accurate, as only then will exceptions be properly received by SAP Cloud ALM.

Step 5: Configure Monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM

In this step, we will now configure Integration & Exception Monitoring of your SAP PaPM Cloud in SAP Cloud ALM. See Activate Data Collection for a Service or System for more details.

Follow the procedure below to add the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud service.

In the Home Screen of your SAP Cloud ALM, go to the Operations tab then select Integration & Exception Monitoring. The application will then open in a new window.

In the Integration & Exception monitoring screen: (a) select Scope to begin selection of the SAP PaPM Cloud application; (b) Under the Managed Components, select Services from the drop-down list; (c) In Service Status, select all services in the SAP Cloud ALM; (d) choose the solution you want to configure the Integration and Exception Monitoring; and (e) click Apply to enter your selection.

 

Tip: Click the Refresh button in SAP Cloud ALM and set the interval to 15 seconds. This will keep your screen view updated.

Select the application you want to configure by clicking the Action button, then select Edit Configuration

You will need to enable the Events first, then the Monitoring, to initiate the monitoring configuration. To do this, select the Service Name under the Services/System.

Select the Events tab, then click Add button.

Use the default settings in the Event Settings section. In the Event Actions section, select the action on how you will be notified in case an alert occurs. You can enable Create Alert to receive event alerts in the Alerting page of the Integration and Exception Monitoring.

Additionally, you can enable Send Email To event action to send emails to notify recipient about the event alert. To use the Send Email To event action, you will need to configure SAP Cloud ALM‚Äôs Notification Management, see Notification Management: Maintaining Recipients . Click the Save button save your configuration.

In the Events screen, you should now see the Event Name ‚ÄúErroneous database-connectivity‚Äù. Also, ensure that the Active status is set to On. Click the Save button to save changes. You can confirm that the changes were applied by checking that the Last Changed By and Last Changed At fields have been updated. We have now completed the Events configuration.

The next step is to enable the Monitoring, go to the Monitoring tab, switch the database-connectivity category to Active (On), and click Save. To confirm the changes, check that the Last Changed By and Last Changed At fields have been updated.  

The last step in this configuration is to enable the Data Collection. Navigate to the Services/Systems, then switch Data Collection to On, and click Save to confirm the changes. Once saved, select Close to finish the configuration.

To confirm the setup is complete, return to the Configuration of your SAP PaPM Cloud service, then you should see database-connectivity configuration category is listed with Data Collection switched On. Additionally, the Last Change By and Last Changed At should show the latest update.

Helpful Notes:

  • In the SAP Cloud ALM Landscape Management, the service added should now display a status of Active. In the Supported Use Cases, Configuration Status for Exception Monitoring, Alert Management and Notification Management (if configured) is set to Active as well.   

  • For BYOD subscription, you can also configure additional monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM for your SAP HANA Cloud and SAP Datasphere. For more details, refer to SAP Cloud ALM: Supported Solutions

Step 6: Configure SAP Cloud ALM Destination in Settings

The final step is to add the destination name in the Settings application of SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model.

In the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud Standard Model, open the Settings application. There, add the required destination name and configure the integration options. You may also include the SAP Cloud ALM URL if needed. You may refer to the Settings for more details.

Note: You can skip this step if you use the default destination name (PaPM_CloudALM) in Step #4.

Setup is complete. What comes next?

After completion of the setup, your solution should appear on the Integration & Exception Monitoring page. By selecting Exceptions from the left-hand navigation, you will be able to view the corresponding exception details for your service.

Question:

Why does the database-connectivity category not reflect the alerts observed in the Database Explorer following setup?

Answer:

In the Configuration, the database-connectivity category for monitoring is set to Push as its data collection mode. This means that the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud service is responsible in sending its monitoring data directly to SAP Cloud ALM.

How can I validate that the Integration and Exception Monitoring for SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud service is working in SAP Cloud ALM?

To confirm that Integration and Exception Monitoring is functioning correctly, you can validate the setup by observing a database connectivity error or intentionally simulating an error in the SAP PaPM Cloud. For instance, this can be achieved by stopping the DPAgent or introducing an authorization issue in the database schema. Once the error occurs, the system will forward the monitoring data to SAP Cloud ALM, where you can navigate to Exceptions to review the error details.ALM.

Additional Note: If you enable the Send Email To and the Notification Management is configured properly, you will be able to receive an email if an alert is triggered.

If you‚Äôve made it this far ‚Äì CONGRATULATIONS! Now is the perfect time to put everything into action and see firsthand how Integration and Exception Monitoring can strengthen your SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud. üòä

entry.title: Re: Different Settlement Material to be used for single c...
entry.content:
Why split criteria is not solving because, split criteria allow you to have multiple settlement lines in the settlement document (e.g. one per product hierarchy). But the settlement material is still taken from the header, so all lines use the same material. There is no standard field in CCM to assign different settlement materials per split criterion.

Options to achieve your requirement

Create one condition contract per product hierarchy. Each contract has its own settlement material. Business volume is restricted to that hierarchy via the condition contract selection criteria. This is the cleanest standard way, but it means more contracts to manage.

SAP provides BAdIs in CCM settlement processing. You can enhance logic to replace the settlement material dynamically based on split criterion (e.g. product hierarchy). This way, one contract can generate settlement lines with different materials. Requires development effort but keeps contract volume lower.

entry.title: Re: Prevent approval/rejection of forwarded workflow task...
entry.content:
Hi Anouk,

in the current cloud release or beginning with OP2025 you should be able to implement BAdI SWF_CHECK_ACTION_ALLOWED. This BAdI runs before BAdI /IWWRK/IF_WF_WI_BEFORE_UPD_IB hence you can check the authorization there and decide to disallow the approval of the task depending on the user.

This BAdI is designed to be only implemented by customers, so there should not be any SAP implementations of the BAdI.

Best regards,

Mazlum

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Public Cloud ‚Äì Error when creating billing do...
entry.content:
The message ‚Äúdate should be less than 20251128‚Äù is a FI posting date check. The posting date of the billing document must lie within an open posting period defined in Financial Accounting (OB52 equivalent, app ‚ÄúManage Posting Periods‚Äù). If the billing date you enter is outside the open posting interval, the system rejects it with this error. The ‚ÄúFinalized‚Äù status of the preliminary billing document means the system is ready to create the real billing document and accounting posting, so the FI posting date rules apply strictly.

Why it works in other tenants could be because in those tenants, the posting period variant for the company code would have been configured to allow postings into future dates (e.g. December 2025 is already open). In your tenant, only periods up to November 2025 are open, so the system enforces ‚Äúdate < 20251128‚Äù.

To fix this, check posting period variant assignment for your company code. In the Manage Posting Periods app, open the next period (December 2025) for the relevant account types (usually ‚Äú+‚Äù for all accounts). Once the future period is open, you can create billing documents with a billing/posting date in December. If you want to allow ‚Äúfuture‚Äëdated‚Äù billing systematically, you can open multiple periods ahead (e.g. current + next month).

entry.title: SAP PaPM (On Premise) Integration with SAC using Multi Action
entry.content:
Introduction

In today‚Äôs fast-paced business landscape, organizations need agile and intelligent solutions that enable them to derive actionable insights from complex financial and operational data. SAP Profitability and Performance Management (PaPM) 3.0 has long served as a powerful modeling and calculation engine, capable of handling vast volumes of data and delivering detailed performance insights.

With the increasing demand for automation and real-time decision-making, integrating SAP PaPM On-Premise with SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) Multi Actions opens up new possibilities. This integration empowers users to not only visualize data but also trigger processes directly from SAC stories ‚Äî enabling a seamless loop from insight to action.

In this blog post, we‚Äôll walk through how you can connect SAP PaPM On-Premise to SAC using PaPM API, and demonstrate how to leverage SAC Multi Actions to initiate PaPM processes ‚Äî enhancing collaboration between planning, simulation, and execution. As a specific use case, this post aims to showcase that users can create and edit a Process Template in PaPM On-Premise directly through SAC Multi Actions, enabling end-to-end process control from within SAC.

Publish OData Services

To integrate the processing service, you need to publish the service group following the steps below:

1. Execute transaction /IWBEP/V4_ADMIN.
a. On the SAP Backend Service Administration screen, choose Register Group in the header menu.
b. In the Register Service Group window, add /NXI/P1_N to Service Group.
c. Add NXI Service Group for OData V4 to Description.
d. Add /NXI/P1_FW to Package and then, choose OK.


e. Generate a Workbench request.

2. On the SAP Backend Service Administration screen, choose Register Service in the header menu.
a. In the Register Service window, add /NXI/P1_CONN_OVRS to Service ID.
b. Add /NXI/CL_P1_CONN_OVRS_MP to Model Provider Class.
c. Add /NXI/CL_P1_CONN_OVRS_DP to Data Provider Class.
d. Add OData V4 Service for Overrules Connections to Description.
e. Add /NXI/P1_FW to Package and then, choose OK.

f. Generate a Workbench request.

3. On the SAP Backend Service Administration screen, choose Register Service in the header menu.
a. In the Register Service window, add /NXI/P1_SYS_USER_DATA to Service ID.
b. Add /NXI/CL_P1_SYS_USER_DATA_MP to Model Provider Class.
c. Add /NXI/CL_P1_SYS_USER_DATA_DP to Data Provider Class.
d. Add User Data to Description.
e. Add /NXI/P1_FW to Package and then, choose OK.


f. Generate a Workbench request.

4. On the SAP Backend Service Administration screen, choose Register Service in the header menu.
a. In the Register Service window, add /NXI/P1_VH_TEAMS to Service ID.
b. Add /NXI/CL_P1_VH_TEAMS_MP to Model Provider Class.
c. Add /NXI/CL_P1_VH_TEAMS_DP to Data Provider Class.
d. Add Value Help for Teams to Description.
e. Add /NXI/P1_FW to Package and then, choose OK.

f. Generate a Workbench request.

5. Publish the /NXI/P1_N service group. To do this, perform the following steps:
a. Execute transaction /IWFND/V4_ADMIN.
b. On the SAP Gateway Service Administration screen, choose Publish Service Groups in the header menu.
c. In the SAP Gateway Service Publishing window, set the System Alias field to LOCAL.
d. Choose Get Service Groups in the header menu.


e. The system lists all unpublished service groups. Select the /NXI/P1_N service group.
f. Choose Publish Service Groups in the toolbar and then, choose OK.
g. Generate a Customizing request.
h. Go back to the SAP Gateway Service Administration screen. In the Available Services section, you can now see the /NXI/P1_N service group.

6. Publish the /NXI/P1_SERVICES service group. To do this, perform the following steps:
a. Execute transaction /IWFND/V4_ADMIN.
b. On the SAP Gateway Service Administration screen, choose Publish Service Groups in the header menu.
c. In the SAP Gateway Service Publishing window, set the System Alias field to LOCAL.
d. Choose Get Service Groups in the header menu.


e. The system lists all unpublished service groups. Select the /NXI/P1_SERVICES service group.
f. Choose Publish Service Groups in the toolbar and then, choose OK.
g. Generate a Customizing request.
h. Go back to the SAP Gateway Service Administration screen. In the Available Services section, you can now see the /NXI/P1_SERVICES service group.

7. Check whether the Processing API service is on version two, ‚Äú0002‚Äù. To do this, execute transaction /IWFND/V4_ADMIN, choose /NXI/P1_SERVICES, and then choose version ‚Äú0002‚Äù of /NXI/P1_PROCESSING, which should be available for your selection. If version ‚Äú0002‚Äù is not available and the API service is still on version ‚Äú0001‚Äù, perform the following steps to create version ‚Äú0002‚Äù:

a. Execute transaction SE38 and run the program /IWBEP/R_V4_ADMIN_SERVICES.
b. Select the /NXI/P1_SERVICES service group from the tree on the left-hand side of the screen.
c. Choose Service Implementation.
d. Choose Register Service.
e. Add /NXI/P1_PROCESSING to Service ID.
f. Add ‚Äú0002‚Äù as the service version.
g. Add /NXI/CL_P1_PROCESSING_MP to Model Provider Class.
h. Add /NXI/CL_P1_PROCESSING_DP to Data Provider Class.
i. Add OData V4 Processing Service to Description.
j. Add /NXI/P1_FW to Package.


k. Choose OK
l. Generate a Workbench request.

After creating version ‚Äú0002‚Äù of the Processing API service, you can either choose to delete version ‚Äú0001‚Äù or keep it as it is.

Mapping PaPM On-Premise in SAP Cloud Connector

As a prerequisite, ensure that the SAP Cloud Connector is properly installed and connected to your SAP BTP subaccount. Once the Cloud Connector is installed and connected to your SAP BTP subaccount, the next step is to map you SAP PaPM On Premise so that SAC can securely consume its services. This mapping ensures that SAC requests are correctly routed to the backend system.

1. Log in to Cloud Connector
a. Open the Cloud Connector Admin UI in your browser.
b. Log in with your administrator credentials.
c. Confirm that your BTP subaccount is already configured and shows as Connected.

2. Add the PaPM On-Premise System
a. Navigate to Cloud To On-Premise in the left panel.
b. Click + Add System Mapping.

c. Choose ABAP System as the backend type (PaPM runs on NetWeaver ABAP).
d. Fill in:

  • Internal Host -> The on-premise PaPM application server host
  • Internal Port -> Usually 44300 or 443 if HTTPS is enabled
  • Protocol -> HTTPS (recommended)

3. Configure Virtual Host and Port
a. Define a Virtual Host and Virtual Port.
b. SAC will use this virtual address when making calls.
c. Example:

  • Virtual Host: papm-onpremise
  • Virtual Port: 443

4. Maintain Resources
a. After system mapping, click + Add Resources of the System.
b. Add the relevant paths for PaPM services

5. Check Status
a. Once saved, Cloud Connector should show the new system as Reachable.
b. Test the mapping by expanding the entry and confirming the green status icon.

Note: The Cloud Connector mapping ensures SAC never directly accesses your internal network. Instead, SAC communicates with the virtual host, and the Cloud Connector securely forwards requests to your on-premise PaPM system.

Creating a PaPM API Connection in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

After mapping your PaPM On-Premise system in the Cloud Connector, the next step is to establish the connection in SAC. Using the PaPM API connection type ensures SAC can directly trigger processes and exchange data with your on-premise environment.

1. Navigate to SAC Connections
a. In SAC, go to the Main Menu -> Connections.
b. Click + Add Connection.

2. Select the Connection type
a. Under SAP PaPM, choose PaPM API.

b. This option is purpose-built for PaPM integrations (use this instead of a generic HTTP API).

3. Provide Connection Details

  • Connection Name: Enter a meaningful name (e.g., PaPM_OnPremise_API).
  • Description: Optional but recommended for clarity.
  • Data Service URL: Enter the Virtual Host defined in the Cloud Connector (e.g., papm-onpremise) and the Virtual Port defined (e.g., 443). Include the link from /NXI/P1_PROCESSING service
    (e.g. https://internal-backend:443/sap/opu/odata4/nxi/p1_services/default/nxi/p1_processing/0002/ )

Note: The Cloud Connector mapping ensures SAC never directly accesses your internal network. Instead, SAC communicates with the virtual host, and the Cloud Connector securely forwards requests to your on-premise PaPM system.

4. Authentication Settings

  • Authentication Method: Select Basic Authentication.
  • Username / Password: Enter the technical user created in PaPM backend for SAC integration.

Note: Ensure that the technical user has the required roles and authorizations in SAP PaPM to enable API access. For detailed information on the specific roles and permissions, refer to the official PaPM authorization documentation.

Note: To enable the checkbox ‚ÄúConnect to an On-Premise PaPM service‚Äù, you must follow the steps below:

  1. Go to Main Menu -> Administration
  2. Click Data Source Configuration

  1. In On-Premise Data Sources, click + Add a new location
  2. In the new pop up window, leave everything blank and Enable Agent Off.

  1. Click Create

6. Save the Connection
a. Click OK to Save the configuration.
b. The new PaPM API connection is now ready for use in Multi Actions.

Using the PaPM Integration Step in SAC Multi Actions

Once your PaPM connection is established in SAC, you can start integrating PaPM processes into SAC workflows. The primary way to do this is through Multi Actions.

1. Create a Multi Action in SAC
a. Go to Main Menu ‚Üí Multi Actions.
b. Click + New Multi Action.

c. Give it a clear name (e.g., SAC and PaPM Integration (API)).

You can also view this link for further information.

2. Add a PaPM Integration Step
a. Inside the Multi Action, click + Add Step.
b. Choose PaPM Integration Step.

c. Select the connection you just created (PaPM_OnPremise).
a. From the dropdown, select the PaPM Process Template or Function you want SAC to trigger.
b. Common use cases: allocations, calculations, rule execution.
c. Optionally define input parameters (if your PaPM function expects runtime variables like period, version, etc.).

Tip: When the new process is enabled, it will generate a new process and activity in PaPM according to the configured Parameters and Selections. If the Existing Process was chosen as action, it will only use the existing process during the process execution.

New Process

Existing Process

4. Test & Validate
a. Save the Multi Action

5. Embed Multi Action in Stories
a. Open an SAC story.
b. Add a Multi Action Trigger button (from the toolbar).
c. Link it to your Multi Action (Trigger_PaPM_Allocations).
d. Now business users can execute PaPM processes directly from SAC, without leaving their planning or reporting environment.

Why This Matters

By completing this step, you‚Äôve enabled end-to-end integration:

  1. SAC users can trigger PaPM allocations, simulations, or calculations in real time.
  2. Results can be fed back into SAC for reporting, dashboards, or planning cycles.
  3. No manual jumping between systems ‚Äî it‚Äôs all connected.

Conclusion

With the integration between SAP PaPM On-Premise and SAP Analytics Cloud, you‚Äôve connected powerful profitability and performance management capabilities directly into your planning and reporting workflows.

  • The Cloud Connector provides secure connectivity.
  • The PaPM API connection in SAC enables seamless process triggering.
  • Multi Actions bring automation, letting business users run allocations and calculations on demand.
  • Finally, by consuming PaPM results inside SAC models and stories, you close the loop between planning, simulation, and analysis.

This setup not only streamlines processes but also empowers users to act on insights in real time, without leaving SAC. By unifying calculation, planning, and reporting, organizations can achieve faster decisions, stronger governance, and greater flexibility.

With the foundation in place, you can now explore advanced topics such as parameterized triggers, scheduling with the SAC Calendar, or extending scenarios with custom APIs and add-ons.

entry.title: Db2 LUW Intra-Partition Parallelism: Tackling Latch Waits in Highly Selective Queries
entry.content:
Motivation

Have you ever encountered a simple, highly selective query that should return quickly, but instead causes slowdowns and high wait times in an SAP on Db2 for Linux, UNIX, and Windows (LUW) environment?

This blog post explores a scenario where highly selective SQL statements that use intra-partition parallelism (IPPs) can suffer from severe overhead, particularly in the form of latch waits. You'll learn to identify this problematic pattern, understand its root cause and discover ways to resolve this issue. I‚Äôll give you an example from an SAP Landscape Transformation (SLT) environment, but the principle applies to any system running similar high-frequency, selective lookups.

Background

Intra-partition parallelism (IPP) is beneficial for complex analytical queries that scan millions of rows. This feature allows the database to break a single SQL query into smaller pieces and execute them simultaneously using multiple parallel subagents.

But how do these agents combine their results?

This is where Table Queues (TQs) come in. A TQ is a shared memory area that acts like a temporary pipeline. Subagents scan the data and push rows that match the query's conditions into the TQ. The coordinator agent pulls the rows from the TQ to assemble the final result. Since multiple agents access this shared pipeline simultaneously, this process requires coordination. Latches provide this coordination, ensuring only one agent modifies the TQ at a time.

Latches are very fast, short-term locks that Db2 uses to protect its own internal memory structures. Do not confuse this with a database lock, whose purpose is to protect user data in tables. When a task needs to read or write to an internal shared structure, it takes a latch, performs its work, and releases it very quickly. If many tasks try to get the same latch at the same time, they form a queue, and the waiting time can add up.

Symptoms

The system suffered from unstable performance and severe slowdowns. The monitoring views in the DBA Cockpit (transaction DBACOCKPIT) revealed the following symptoms:

High Latch Wait Time (transaction DBACOCKPIT -> Performance -> Time Spent Analysis) 

Over 85% of the database's time was spent waiting on latches.

 Specific Latch Contention (transaction DBACOCKPIT -> Diagnostics -> Extended Latch Waits)

The following three latches were by far the most expensive ones:

  • sqkfSessionLockManager and sqkfRecvLockManager (Protect the TQ)
  • SQLB_BPD__bpdLatch_SX (Protects the Buffer Pool's metadata. High contention means many parallel agents are competing to access data pages from memory, creating a bottleneck in the query's data reading phase.)

 Problematic Queries (transaction DBACOCKPIT -> Performance -> Top SQL Statements - sorted by Total Extended Latch Wait Time)

SQL statements, responsible for the vast majority of the wait time, followed a distinct pattern:

  • They used a highly selective WHERE clause to find a specific record.
  • They included FETCH FIRST 1 ROW ONLY (or LIMIT 1) to retrieve only that record.
  • Parallelism and TQs were used in the access plan.

This pattern is common in job-polling or status-tracking applications. In our specific case, it was an SAP Landscape Transformation (SLT) system constantly polling its control tables (IUUC_RS_STATUS, IUUC_RS_ORDER) to find the latest status record, marked by the flag IS_LAST = 'X'.

Root Cause

The application is designed to perform a simple and quick lookup and return one specific row. However, the database access plan told a different story:

Statement:

The IUUC_RS_STATUS table is a log used by SLT to track the replication status of a specific source table. Every time the status changes (e.g., replication starts, a load finishes, or an error occurs), SLT inserts a new row into this table with a timestamp. The IS_LAST = 'X' flag is used to mark the single, most recent, and currently active status record. This is why SLT constantly queries for the row with IS_LAST = 'X' and LIMIT 1.

Access Plan:

Used Index:

The index IUUC_RS_STATUS-0 on the table IUUC_RS_STATUS did not include the IS_LAST column. Since the index wasn't a good fit, the Db2 optimizer made a decision: "I can't find this row with a single index lookup. Instead, I'll use multiple parallel agents (intra-partition parallelism) to scan the index faster and find it."

This led to the following normal and expected process:

  1. Db2 establishes the coordinator and subagents and opens the necessary TQ for the parallel sections.
  2. Each subagent scans a portion of the index, looking for rows that match the WHERE clause.
  3. When a subagents finds a matching row, it tries to push it into the shared TQ.
  4. The coordinator agent pulls the first row from the TQ and stops because of LIMIT 1.

However, even though the LIMIT 1 clause allows the coordinator to terminate after retrieving the first qualifying row, the overhead associated with initiating parallel sub-agents and managing the TQ with latches outweighed the benefits for a simple task like finding a single row. While the parallel read performance provided by intra-partition parallelism is advantageous for large analytical queries, it is not beneficial in this context.

In short, for these highly selective lookups, parallelization was counterproductive. The subagents ended up spending more time waiting for latches than performing actual work, making the query, which was expected to be quick, slow and unpredictable.

Fix

In this case, it is crucial that the estimated size of the intermediate result becomes so small that the optimizer recognizes that parallel processing is not beneficial. This example shows that parallelization is not always advantageous, can make the environment more complex and potentially lead to optimizer misjudgments.

The recommended resolution approach is to add a suitable index that covers all columns of the WHERE clause. In this example, the IS_LAST column was missing. This changed the access plan fundamentally:

New index:

        IUUC_RS_STATUS on (MT_ID, TABLE_NAME, IS_LAST)

The effect of this change is that the predicate becomes fully covered by the index columns. This allows Db2 to perform a simple, single-threaded index probe and stop on the first match. Therefore, there is no longer a need for TQs or IPP, and the latch hotspot disappears. The SQL access plan shows a significant decrease in estimated costs, from 2,335E+03 timerons initially to 1,379E+01 timerons after the optimization. This corresponds to a reduction by a factor of approximately 170.

Alternative solutions

Use optimization guidelines

  • These are special instructions (hints) that you can add directly to an SQL statement. They give the database targeted suggestions on how to run a query.
  • To disable parallelism for a single query, you can use the instruction <DEGREE VALUE='1'>. This guarantees that the database will run the statement serially.
  • With these guidelines, you can also influence other behaviors like forcing a specific index. This can also prevent parallelism, but it's only a side effect and isn‚Äôt guaranteed.
  • For more information, see SAP Note 868888 - DB6: Use of DB2 Optimization Guidelines

Disable parallelism globally

  • Set the DB CFG parameter ‚ÄúDFT_DEGREE‚Äù to 1 (sets the default degree of parallelism for all statements to 1).
    Alternatively, set the DBM CFG parameter ‚ÄúINTRA_PARALLEL‚Äù to ‚ÄòNO‚Äô (disables intra-query parallelism at the instance level).
  • All queries across all sessions will be executed without parallelism and there is no need to modify individual statements. However, this affects all workloads, including those that benefit from parallelism. Changing ‚ÄúDFT_DEGREE‚Äú or ‚ÄúINTRA_PARALLEL‚Äú requires a database deactivation/activation.
  • For more information, see Parallel processing for applications and SAP Note 2047006 - DB6: Use of Db2 SMP Parallelism (INTRA_PARALLEL=YES)

Verification and Monitoring

Inspect the execution plan of affected statements:

In the DBA Cockpit (transaction DBACOCKPIT - SQL Cache), check the EXPLAIN plan or use MON_GET_PKG_CACHE_STMT. Look for TQs and the query degree. After adding the new index or disabling the parallelism, the plan should be a straightforward index probe with no TQs.

Compare waits before/after:

To observe the total extended latch wait time, inspect the DBA Cockpit (transaction DBACOCKPIT - Time Spent Analysis). For latch types and agent behavior, use the DBA Cockpit (transaction DBACOCKPIT -  Extended Latch Waits) or db2pd -latches and db2pd -agents.

Conclusion

Intra-partition parallelism (IPP) can significantly boost the performance of analytics and batch workloads. However, it may also result in costly access plans and increased latch wait times, especially with highly selective queries, such as those common in SAP Landscape Transformation (SLT) setups, if these queries lack proper index support. Keep in mind that this issue is not exclusive to SLT queries and can occur in various scenarios. The optimizer may choose to use IPP with latch-protected Table Queues (TQs), which lead to significant overhead in this specific situation. For these selective queries, the startup and coordination cost of TQs can dominate the processing time, resulting in substantial delays.

By creating a targeted index that includes relevant columns (e.g., the IS_LAST column for SLT logging tables), Db2 can perform a single-threaded index probe and return the desired row very fast. This eliminates the latch hotspot without compromising overall system parallelism. While disabling parallelism is an alternative solution, creating the appropriate index is a more efficient and targeted approach.

Have you used intra-partition parallelism in your system? Share your thoughts and experiences in the comments.

entry.title: Re: CPI HTTP Receiver always returns 400 ‚ÄúSyntax Error‚Äù a...
entry.content:
Hi, we have had the same issue. SAP mentioned after we opened a ticket to try the following thing: Remove the SAP-PASSPORT header

We achieved this by doing the following steps:

In order to remove the SAP-PASSPORT, add a * modifier right before the step making the call to the target system and:

1) set property "SAP_DisablePassportTransmission" to "true"
2) remove header "SAP-PASSPORT"

Regards
David
